{{rfcquote|text=
There have been many internet announcements for the production progress for Prometheus 2 in Nov and Dec 2014, the sequel film to Prometheus, with multiple release dates published for Prometheus 2 in multiple countries including Sweden, Brazil, and USA. Another editor has opposed the inclusion of this production update information and multiply published release dates. The publication of multiple release dates usually is sufficient to justify including further information for Prometheus 2. '''Support''' if the one line summary below of production and release date updates should be included in the sequel section of this article for Prometheus, '''Oppose''' if you believe it should be excluded from this article. [[User:LawrencePrincipe|LawrencePrincipe]] ([[User talk:LawrencePrincipe|talk]]) 15:29, 8 March 2015 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film#rfc_DCE7C75|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: DCE7C75
* User: BattleshipMan
* Date: 2015-03-08 06:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|653194969|MEDIA 653194969}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|655530298|MEDIA 655530298}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I may one other solution for year film articles that were made and produced by certain countries. I'm proposing year of film articles that were release in certain countries that made the films like <nowiki>[[2013 in films in United States of America]]</nowiki>, <nowiki>[[2013 in films in England]]</nowiki>, <nowiki>[[2013 in films in France]]</nowiki> and such. I'm not happy with the film year format on [[2013 in film]] and I'm proposing the alternative idea for films made and produced by a certain & release dates in the country that made and produced the film. I don't care how redundant as it may sound, I'm wont stop until a consensus on that issue is met. [[User:BattleshipMan|BattleshipMan]] ([[User talk:BattleshipMan|talk]]) 06:40, 8 March 2015 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Songs#rfc_B970229|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Songs]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: B970229
* User: Binksternet
* Date: 2015-03-06 22:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|650214231|MEDIA 650214231}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|655530298|MEDIA 655530298}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the [[WP:SONGCOVER]] guideline be loosened to include more sources?
;Existing
{{talkquote|1=
When a song has renditions (recorded or performed) by more than one artist, discussion of a particular artist's rendition should be included in the song's article (never in a separate article), but only if at least one of the following applies:
*the rendition is discussed by a reliable source on the subject of the song (not on the subject of the rendition),
*the rendition itself meets the notability requirement at [[WP:NSONGS]].}}
;Proposed
{{talkquote|1=
When a song has renditions (recorded or performed) by more than one artist, discussion of a particular artist's rendition should be included in the song's article (never in a separate article), but only if it meets the standard inclusion policies of [[WP:V|verifiability]], [[WP:NPOV|neutral point of view]] and [[WP:NOR|no original research]].
* All information about the cover song must be attributed to a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] that mentions both the song and the artist
* The artist should be [[WP:N|notable]] enough for a standalone article
* The [[WP:DUE|due weight]] of the cover depends on its importance and level of coverage in reliable sources. A cover that achieves independent commercial success (eg: [[Joe Cocker]]'s version of "[[With A Little Help From My Friends]]", [[Wet Wet Wet]]'s cover of "[[Love Is All Around]]") should obtain more coverage than a single news report of performing the cover in concert.}}

The proposal would remove the requirement that the reliable source is discussing the song itself, rather than the cover version, and it would remove the requirement that the cover version be notable per NSONGS. [[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] ([[User talk:Binksternet|talk]]) 22:02, 6 March 2015 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Star Wars#rfc_4F590AD|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Star Wars]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: 4F590AD
* User: Kamek98
* Date: 2015-03-05 21:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|650055013|MEDIA 650055013}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|655530298|MEDIA 655530298}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we rename all current six Star Wars films to Star Wars Episode X: Subtitle form (i.e Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi) or move them all to just the subtitle form (i.e. The Phantom Menace) and make the opening lines for the pages something such as the way I have proposed below? Thank you for your time!

This request for comment is not brief, sorry. It happens.

Anyways- opinions, go.

I say, either of these ways will do.
<br>
# Move all pages to ''Star Wars Episode X: Subtitle''
<br>
OR
<br>
#Move ''[[Star Wars (film)]]'' to ''A New Hope'', ''[[Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace]]'' to ''The Phantom Menace'', ''[[Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones]]'' to ''Attack of the Clones'', and ''[[Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith]]'' to ''Revenge of the Sith''.  Then, make the opening lines for the pages something like this:<br>
{| class="wikitable sortable"
|-
! Current article name !! Moved to !! New article name !! Introduction paragraph(s)
|-
| ''[[Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace]]'' || Moved to || ''[[The Phantom Menace]]'' || '''''Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace''''', often referred to as simply '''''The Phantom Menace''''' or '''''Star Wars: The Phantom Menace''''', is a 1999 American [[epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] film written and directed by [[George Lucas]]. It is the fourth film in the ''[[Star Wars]]'' saga to be released, the first of a three-part [[prequel]] to the original ''Star Wars'' trilogy, and the first film in the story chronology. The film was Lucas' first production as a film director after a 22-year hiatus following the [[A New Hope|original ''Star Wars'' film]], and his fourth film overall.
|-
| ''[[Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones]]'' || Moved to || ''[[Attack of the Clones]]'' || '''''Star Wars: Episode II – Attack of the Clones''''', often referred to as simply '''''Attack of the Clones''''' or '''''Star Wars: Attack of the Clones''''', is a 2002 American [[Epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] film directed by [[George Lucas]] and written by Lucas and [[Jonathan Hales]]. It is the fifth film to be released in the ''[[Star Wars]]'' series and stars [[Ewan McGregor]], [[Hayden Christensen]], [[Natalie Portman]], [[Christopher Lee]], [[Ian McDiarmid]], and [[Samuel L. Jackson]]. The film is set 10 years after the events of ''[[The Phantom Menace]]'', when [[Star Wars galaxy|the galaxy]] is on the brink of [[Galactic Civil War|civil war]]. Under the leadership of a renegade [[Jedi]] named [[Count Dooku]], thousands of [[planetary system]]s threaten to [[secession|secede]] from the [[Galactic Republic (Star Wars)|Galactic Republic]]. When an [[assassination]] attempt is made on Senator [[Padmé Amidala]], the former Queen of [[Naboo]], Jedi apprentice [[Darth Vader|Anakin Skywalker]] is assigned to protect her, while his mentor [[Obi-Wan Kenobi]] is assigned to investigate the assassination attempt. Soon, Anakin, Padmé, and Obi-Wan are drawn into the heart of the Separatist territories and the beginning of a new threat to the galaxy, the [[Clone Wars (Star Wars)|Clone Wars]].
|-
| ''[[Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith]]'' || Moved to || ''[[Revenge of the Sith]]'' || '''''Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith''''', often referred to as simply '''''Revenge of the Sith''''' or '''''Star Wars: Revenge of the Sith''''', is a 2005 American [[Epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] film written and directed by [[George Lucas]]. It is the sixth film released in the ''[[Star Wars]]'' franchise and stars [[Ewan McGregor]], [[Natalie Portman]], [[Hayden Christensen]], [[Ian McDiarmid]], [[Samuel L. Jackson]], and [[Christopher Lee]]. The film is set three years after the onset of the [[Clone Wars (Star Wars)|Clone Wars]] and was produced by [[Lucasfilm]] and distributed by [[20th Century Fox]].
|-
| ''[[Star Wars (film)]]'' || Moved to || ''[[A New Hope]]'' || '''''Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope''''', often referred to as simply '''''A New Hope''''', '''''Star Wars: A New Hope''''', or by its original release title of '''''Star Wars''''', is a 1977 American [[Epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] film written and directed by [[George Lucas]]. The first release in the [[Star Wars|''Star Wars'' franchise]], it stars [[Mark Hamill]], [[Harrison Ford]], [[Carrie Fisher]], [[Peter Cushing]], and [[Alec Guinness]]. The plot focuses on the [[Rebel Alliance]], led by [[Princess Leia]] (Fisher), and its attempt to destroy the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]]'s space station, the [[Death Star]]. This conflict disrupts the isolated life of ambitious farmhand [[Luke Skywalker]] (Hamill) when he inadvertently acquires a pair of [[droid (robot)|droids]] that possess stolen [[architectural plan]]s for the Death Star. After the Empire begins a destructive search for the missing droids, Skywalker agrees to accompany [[Jedi|Jedi Master]] [[Obi-Wan Kenobi]] (Guinness) on a mission to return the Death Star plans to the Rebel Alliance and save the galaxy from the tyranny of the Galactic Empire.
|-
| ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'' || Moved to || – || '''''Star Wars: Episode V – The Empire Strikes Back''''', often referred to as simply '''''The Empire Strikes Back''''' or '''''Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back''''', is a 1980 American [[epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] film directed by [[Irvin Kershner]] and produced by [[Gary Kurtz]]. [[Leigh Brackett]] and [[Lawrence Kasdan]] wrote the screenplay, with [[George Lucas]] writing the film's story and serving as executive producer. Of the ''[[Star Wars]]'' films, it was the second to be released and the fifth in terms of internal chronology.

The film is set 3 years after ''[[A New Hope]]''. The [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]], under the leadership of the villainous [[Darth Vader]] and the [[Palpatine|Emperor Palpatine]], is in pursuit of [[Luke Skywalker]] and the rest of the [[Rebel Alliance]]. While Vader chases a small band of Luke's friends—[[Han Solo]], [[Princess Leia Organa]], and others across the galaxy, Luke studies [[Force (Star Wars)|the Force]] under [[Jedi|Jedi Master]] [[Yoda]]. When Vader captures Luke's friends, Luke must decide whether to complete his training and become a full [[Jedi|Jedi Knight]] or to confront Vader and save his comrades.
|-
| ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'' || Moved to || – || '''''Star Wars: Episode VI – Return of the Jedi''''', often referred to as simply '''''Return of the Jedi''''' or '''''Star Wars: Return of the Jedi''''', is a 1983 American [[Epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] film directed by [[Richard Marquand]]. The screenplay by [[Lawrence Kasdan]] and [[George Lucas]] was from a story by Lucas, who was also the executive producer. It is the third film released in the ''[[Star Wars]]'' franchise and the first film to use [[THX]] technology. The film is set one year after ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'' and was produced by [[Howard Kazanjian]] for [[Lucasfilm|Lucasfilm Ltd]]. The film stars [[Mark Hamill]], [[Harrison Ford]], [[Carrie Fisher]], [[Billy Dee Williams]], [[Anthony Daniels]], and [[David Prowse]].
|}

The reason I came up with this idea is because we clearly have done this sort of thing with other pages such as [[The Avengers (2012 film)]] where the actual name, ''Marvel's The Avengers'' is followed by its other common name ''The Avengers''.  In this Star Wars case, people who believe the common name is not with the episode title are satisfied, and the people who believe the full title is the common name are satisfied because the articles introduce the topic by the official name (which again, people would argue is also the common name) and says the shorter "common" names in the same introduction sentence.  This third choice I have suggested would also eliminate the recent discussion about whether using ''Star Wars: Episode X – Subtitle'' or ''Star Wars Episode X: Subtitle'' for the prequels since articles would now just link to the subtitle and they wouldn't have to worry about writing the episode name correctly in the pipe linking or whatever. And face, you know damn well these titles (baring Episode VII, which who the hell knows if Abrams is going to be like "oh yeah, let's call it Star Wars: Episode VII – The Force Awakens" officially) are officially titled and sold under the title written as '''''Star Wars: Episode X – Subtitle'''''. (Unless you want to write it as ''Star Wars: Episode X: Subtitle'' or ''Star Wars, Episode X: Subtitle'', but we can all agree these alternate ways looks really odd as $h!+, commas look odd in this case and two colons looks like just no.) [[User talk:Kamek98|Eric - Contact me please. I prefer conversations started on my talk page if the subject is changed]] 21:28, 5 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Australian politics#rfc_EE8A40E|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Australian politics]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: EE8A40E
* User: ColonialGrid
* Date: 2015-03-03 11:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|649677589|POL 649677589}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|655530303|POL 655530303}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A discussion has started at [[Talk:New South Wales state election, 2015#I think this article was spin-doctored.]] regarding the appropriateness of adding minor parties to infoboxes of election articles. It started when the Greens party, who have one seat in the NSW legislative assembly, was added to the infobox. There seems to be a consensus that minor parties who are represented in lower houses should be included, but nothing firm on what the threshold should be. So, should minor parties be included in infoboxes of Australian state/territorial/federal election articles, and if so, what should the minimum threshold of representation be? [[User:ColonialGrid|ColonialGrid]] ([[User talk:ColonialGrid|talk]]) 11:10, 3 March 2015 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
A few days ago, an editor added this text to the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] article: 

''The party's platform calls for an "all of the above" energy policy including clean energy, natural gas and domestic oil, with the desire of becoming energy independent.''

The source for this was the Democratic Party's homepage, [http://www.democrats.org/democratic-national-platform democrats.org]. Is this an '''encyclopedic description''' of the Democrats' energy policies, or is this a vague political platitude that '''requires clarification''' from [[Wikipedia:SECONDARY|secondary sources]] prior to being considered encyclopedic material? 22:21, 28 February 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:F1 driver results legend 2#rfc_74F38B1|Template talk:F1 driver results legend 2]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: 74F38B1
* User: Prisonermonkeys
* Date: 2015-03-08 09:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|650426536|SOC 650426536}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|650426537|STYLE 650426537}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|655530318|SOC 655530318}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|655530324|STYLE 655530324}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am starting an RfC based on a suggestion above. The results legend currently uses a set of colours to distinguish between individual results in results matrices, such as those that appear in season articles, like [[2014 Formula One season]]. The legend uses blue to represent non-points finishes and purple to represent retirements. However, I feel that this arrangement has the potential to be difficult to read for people who are red/blue colour-blind. I myself am red/green colour-blind, and sometimes find it difficult to distinguish between individual results in a large matrix. The individual cells do have the result (ie 14 for a non-points finish, or Ret for a retirement) written in black, but I do not think that thus goes far enough. Lately the project has emphasised improving the readability for as many users as possible, and with that in mind, I propose changing the colours slightly. As this represents a major change, it would need a consensus from the community, but with very few people having any experience with colour-blindness (I am the only one that I know of), I have opened it up to RfC.

What I propose is changing the colour for non-points finishes to a light blue. As light blue is used elsewhere in the results matrices (albeit very infrequently), I further propose changing it to another colour (perhaps swap with the existing darker blue currently used for non-points finishes). [[User:Prisonermonkeys|Prisonermonkeys]] ([[User talk:Prisonermonkeys|talk]]) 09:38, 8 March 2015 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_F1B6E73|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Good article nominations#rfc_B7E456C|Wikipedia talk:Good article nominations]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: B7E456C
* Date: 2015-03-08 01:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|650383048|POLICY 650383048}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|650939074|POLICY 650939074}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Today I would like to bring to the attention of the community an article that just today failed GAN, [[Bikini]], and why this article's experience at GAN leads me to believe that the following element of the GA [[Wikipedia:Good article nominations/Instructions|review criteria]]:
{{quote|Note that the standard holding time is seven days; however, reviewers can shorten/extend the time limit if they wish.}}
Needs to be modified.

This article failed its [[Talk:Bikini/GA1|first GA nomination]] in January of 2014 under the authorship of [[User:Azx2|Azx2]] for important structural reasons that were never addressed during the review; nonetheless despite [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Bikini/GA1&action=history minimal] activity on the page I think it is important to point out that long-time reviewer [[User:TonyTheTiger|TonyTheTiger]] started the review on 16 December 2013 and did not finally fail the article until 11 January 2014, a period of just under a month. This is an advisable level of discretion that I have also attempted to practice in my own reviews and have indeed come to expect from my reviewers as well.

For instance, when I [[Talk:Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles/GA1|reviewed]] [[Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles]] also in January 2014 nominator [[User:EnigmaMcmxc|EnigmaMcmxc]] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3AArticle_231_of_the_Treaty_of_Versailles%2FGA1&diff=588407986&oldid=588149339 stated] that "I am currently suffering from the flu. Is it possible for the deadline to be extended by about a week, until I am feeling better and able to work on the recommendations and the article?". My immediate reply was to [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Article_231_of_the_Treaty_of_Versailles/GA1&diff=next&oldid=588407986 assure him] that "Take what time you need, I've always seen "two weeks" as more a suggestion than a rule." Later on the situation reversed itself; I was unavailable to finish the review and it was Enigma's turn to wait the week that was necessary for me to unbury myself. End result: the article passed GA. Everyone wins.

As you all know, GAN has an enormous and almost consistently-growing backlog of articles to review and as a result a lot of the article that are put up for GA review have been listed for months or more. In the intervening time a lot of things can happen IRL that take an editor's attention away from Wikipedia. Another example: in 2010 [[User:Casliber|Casliber]], another superlatively experienced editor, began reviewing ''my'' nomination at the time, [[Davidson Seamount]]. The original review came down on the 6th of February; my [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3ADavidson_Seamount%2FGA1&diff=344729052&oldid=342241980 response] did not come until the 17th&mdash;I had simply not logged into Wikipedia in the intervening time and quite frankly ''forgotten'' I had a nomination listed at all! When I "rediscovered" this fact I very nearly did a flip&mdash;I felt so lucky to have gotten a reviewer who knew the virtues of patience! The rest of the procedure was [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Davidson_Seamount/GA1&action=history short and sweet]. End result: article passed GA; everyone wins. 

[[User:Aditya Kabir|Aditya Kabir]] had been working to slowly but consistently bring the [[Bikini]] article up in quality from shortly after it failed its first GA nomination. In June of 2014 he listed his article for peer review; [[Wikipedia:Peer review/Bikini/archive1|I reviewed it]]. All of my points were handled and we've maintained a cordial relationship since then; though I wasn't willing to handle the GA nomination (and didn't think that, having already been involved in a PR, that was advisable) I watched with interest and [[User_talk:Aditya_Kabir#On_.22bikini.22|encouragement]] (something so ''rarely'' seen on here nowadays&mdash;but I digress). He finally felt confident enough to [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Bikini&oldid=635653987 nominate] the article in November. Between the time that he put it up for review to the time that it was reviewed and placed [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Bikini&oldid=649160590 on hold], exactly three months passed (27 November to 27 February). [[User:SNUGGUMS|SNUGGUMS]] was the reviewer, and an [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Bikini/GA2&oldid=649335571 initial comment] on the [[Talk:Bikini/GA2|review page]] was "I don't think there's too many problems".

Then the following exchange occurred, which I <big>'''''strongly'''''</big> believe is wrong, wrong, wrong, wrong, wrong:

#[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3ABikini%2FGA2&diff=650024269&oldid=650018746 this has made progress] - S
#[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Bikini/GA2&action=history I hope I can address all issues] - Kabir
#[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3ABikini%2FGA2&diff=650067090&oldid=650064495 So do I. '''You've got 25 hours'''] - S
#[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3ABikini%2FGA2&diff=650214829&oldid=650067090 Can you please extent the deadline a little bit?] - Kabir (edit summary: please)
#[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Bikini/GA2&diff=next&oldid=650214829 '''While this is being failed for now''', but your efforts are commendable and you did well.] [sic] - S (edit summary: failing)
#[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3ABikini&diff=650226477&oldid=649160590 '''GA Fail''']

My fellow Wikipedians. This is unacceptable. When an editor who is actively working on a nomination asks for an extension to allow them to continue the work they are doing on the article in question, you don't fail the GAN whilst doling out pity in your failing statement; you ought to have no right to do so; you ''ought'' to consider the activity of the editor in question and, gauging the situation, offer whichever length of an extension you deem necessary for the writer to do what they're there to do&mdash;improve the encyclopedia. This ''ought'' to be the way we operate, and it ''ought'' to be what the guidelines say. I don't know how quickly GA reviews were once handled in the past, when this particular element of the nominations procedure was created&mdash;perhaps S even felt generous, he had granted twice the allotted time after all&mdash;but if an editor has to wait ''three '''months''''' for their article to finally be reviewed, the reviewer can wait more than ''one '''week''''' for the necessary work to be finished.

I propose that the guidelines on review length be rewritten to better fit what I believe the situation has always been anyway and always ought to be:
{{quote|Note that there is no standard holding time; reviewers can shorten/extend their time limit as they wish, taking into consideration the level of activity the nomination has generated and whether or not the nominator has asked for an extension given their off-wiki circumstances. The ultimate goal of a good article nomination is a good article&mdash;the reviewer should allow whatever time they believe necessary to allow this to happen.}}

It's furthermore unfair to Kabir that he must wait another expected three months for his article to be reviewed again, and I petition that this review be reopened and the editor given a time extension.

Thank you. <span style="font-family:Verdana,Arial,Helvetica"><b><font color="#333" size="2">[[User:Resident Mario|Res]]</font></b><font color="#444" size="2">[[User_talk:Resident_Mario#top|Mar]]</font></span> 01:29, 8 March 2015 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Harassment#rfc_B3B42FC|Wikipedia talk:Harassment]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: B3B42FC
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2015-03-04 21:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|649182121|POLICY 649182121}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|655530333|POLICY 655530333}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
<s>I propose the addition of "Link to accounts on other websites through which paid editing appears to be taking place may be used on Wikipedia during discussion at [[WP:COIN]]. This includes accounts from websites such as [[Elance]] or from websites that specialize in Wikipedia editing such as [http://www.wikilinkpro.com/ WikiLinkPro] among others."</s>

Amended proposal:


[[WP:OUTING]] already says: "Posting links to other accounts on other websites is allowable on a case by case basis." 

Add, following that: For example, links to freelancing sites or other sites involved in soliciting paid editing, where editors disclose their Wikipedia usernames, take paid editing jobs, or provide examples of Wikipedia articles they have written for pay, or the like, may be used to address issues related to paid editing. <small>(note - amended proposal per discussion below [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 21:48, 4 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Fire engine#rfc_CCDD66A|Talk:Fire engine]] expired 2015-04-08 16:14 ===
* Id: CCDD66A
* User: Zackmann08
* Date: 2015-03-08 22:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|650519667|UNSORTED 650519667}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|655530351|UNSORTED 655530351}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
So I think we all know this page needs some help. It is way to big and confusing. Here is an idea I had. Anyone with actual knowledge of the fire service knows that the terms "fire engine" and "fire truck" are NOT interchangeable! A truck has some sort of aerial ladder or platform. What do people think about pulling all of the aerial apparatus out to their own page ([[fire truck]]). This page would still have an "Aerial apparatus" section but it would just have 2-3 sentences saying this is what distinguishes a TRUCK from an ENGINE, then directing you to the [[fire truck]] page. For example, look at the section on [[Fire_engine#Aircraft|Aircraft]]. One sentence and a 'Main Article:' link, or [[Fire_engine#Fireboat|Fireboat]]. Thoughts? --[[User:Zackmann08|Zackmann08]] ([[User talk:Zackmann08|talk]]) 22:40, 8 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Neutral point of view/Noticeboard#rfc_5D1D2A8|Wikipedia:Neutral point of view/Noticeboard]] expired 2015-04-09 01:00 ===
* Id: 5D1D2A8
* User: Ret.Prof
* Date: 2015-03-10 00:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|655530312|RELI 655530312}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|655610870|RELI 655610870}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{Mbox|text=This has been cited at [[Wikipedia:Administrators' noticeboard/Incidents#John Carter and Ret.Prof]]|type=notice}}
'''THE PROBLEM:''' is that nobody knows when the [[Gospel of Matthew]] was written, as it is undated. Many scholars such as [https://www.google.de/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=Date+majority+view+%22A+pre-70+date+for+Matthew+remains+a+minority+view%22+%22strongly+supported%22 France 2007 p19] believe it was composed around 85CE.  Others state it may have been written as early as '''''50 CE'''''. See  [http://www.google.de/search?q=%22the+Gospel+of+Matthew+was+the+first+Gospel+account+written%2C+perhaps+a+date+somewhere+around+a.d.+50%22&tbm=bks&hl=en&spell=1&oq=&gs_l= REF1], [https://www.google.de/search?q=NIV+prior+%22Some+scholars+have+proposed+a+date+as+early+as+AD+50.%22&tbm=bks&hl=en&nfpr=&spell=1&oq=&gs_l= REF2], 
, [http://books.google.de/books?id=fpu-Pl7W_UIC&pg=PA1253&dq=%22Matthew+also+called+Levi%22+%22c.+A.D.+50%22+%22Date+of+writing%22+%22c.+A.D.+50%22+%22Date+of+writing%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-UAYVNPjHIygyATthIL4Bg&ved=0CBkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Matthew%20also%20called%20Levi%22%20%22c.%20A.D.%2050%22%20%22Date%20of%20writing%22%20%22c.%20A.D.%2050%22%20%22Date%20of%20writing%22&f=false REF3], [http://www.google.de/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22Most+Bible+scholars+believe+Matthew%27s+gospel+was+written+between+A.d.+50%22 REF4], [http://www.google.de/search?q=Gospel+Matthew+%22Features+of+Matthew%27s+gospel+may+help+us+narrow+the+time+frame+between+AD+50%22&tbm=bks&hl=en&spell=1&oq=&gs_l= REF5] [http://www.google.de/search?q=%22The+NKJV%22+%22matthew+wrote+Jesus%22+%22It+is+reasonable+to+conclude+that+the+book+was+written+sometime+between+A.D.+50+and+60%22&tbm=bks&hl=en&oq=&gs_l= REF6],
[http://www.google.de/search?q=%22Date+and+Place+of+Writing%22+%22Matthew%27s+Gospel+was+written+in%22+%22the+early+part+of+A.D.+50+%22+-KING&tbm=bks&hl=en&oq=&gs_l= REF7]  Reference books such as [http://www.google.de/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22The+date+of+the+composition+of+Matthew%27s+gospel+is+unknown%2C+and+scholars+have+set+the+time+anywhere+between+A.D.+50+and+115.%22 The Zondervan Encyclopedia of the Bible, 2010] simply state that scholars have set the time anywhere between 50 and 115.

'''MAURICE CASEY:''' who is one of the world's leading Biblical scholars published   ''[https://www.google.de/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22I+propose+that+it+should+be+dated+much+earlier+than+this%2C+c.50%E2%80%9360+CE%22&gws_rd=ssl Jesus of Nazareth]''  in 2010. This work came down in favour of the 50-60 CE date.  Then several months ago Casey published ''[https://www.google.de/search?q=50+%22+collector.+I+conclude+that+the+Gospel+of+Matthew+is+a+major+source+for+our+knowledge+of+the+life+and+teaching+of+Jesus%2C+written+c.+50–60+ce.%22&tbm=bks&hl=en&oq=&gs_l= Jesus: Evidence and Argument or Mythicist Myths? 2014]'' which laid out the the scholarly argument for his position. See pp 93 ff 

'''THE SPECIFIC CHANGE BEING PROPOSED:''' See [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gospel_of_Matthew&diff=625539772&oldid=625523391 Diff 1] [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Gospel_of_Matthew&diff=next&oldid=625539772 Diff 2]

'''DEBATE:''' [[Talk:Gospel of Matthew/Archive 11#NPOV dispute and edit warring|GOSPEL OF MATTHEW (talk) - NPOV ''dispute and edit warring'']].

'''CLARIFICATION NEEDED:''' Is the deletion of the early 50 CE date a violation of WP:NPOV? Also can a number of editors form [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Gospel_of_Matthew&diff=prev&oldid=627893040 a "consensus that policies regarding NPOV do not apply" to this article?] If so in what circumstances? -  [[User:Ret.Prof|Ret.Prof]] ([[User talk:Ret.Prof|talk]]) 00:06, 10 March 2015 (UTC)}}

I am curious about the notability of [[Line of duty death]]s and their inclusion in this article. To be clear, I by NO MEANS want to diminish the sacrifice or anything of that nature. The department I am close to just lost a firefighter last week. But I am curious if this merits inclusion. There are certainly some cases where they do. The [[Granite Mountain Hotshots]] for example, or the [[Emergency workers killed in the September 11 attacks]]. But in both cases those killed are not listed on the departments page, but in separate articles. I recommend not including this list in articles but would like to get other's input. --[[User:Zackmann08|Zackmann08]] ([[User talk:Zackmann08|talk]]) 17:33, 10 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Medical disclaimer#rfc_A0387C6|Wikipedia talk:Medical disclaimer]] expired 2015-04-09 23:00 ===
* Id: A0387C6
* User: Jayron32
* Date: 2015-03-25 16:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|653480992|POLICY 653480992}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|655749600|POLICY 655749600}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RFC also applies to:
*[[Wikipedia:Reference desk/Guidelines/Medical advice]]
*[[User:Kainaw/Kainaw's criterion]]
*[[Template:RD-deleted]]

Per recent discussions at [[WT:RD]] it seems clear that this policy does not have consensus.  See for example [[Wikipedia talk:Reference desk#What is wrong with this?|this recent discussion]] or discussions [[Wikipedia talk:Reference desk/Guidelines/Medical advice|here]].  Wikipedia policy should reflect consensus, and it is clear that there is no consensus to support the prohibition against giving medical advice.  I am asking for an RFC to deprecate this policy, and related pages, including [[Wikipedia:Reference desk/Guidelines/Medical advice]].  For this reason, I propose that our rules reflect the desire of the community: that these pages be marked historical, and that these policies, pages, and templates be deprecated.  I don't really care personally one way or the other, but if the community doesn't support this policy, it should be deprecated.  If the community does support this policy, then we should enforce it.  We shouldn't have a situation where a policy is on the books without consensus. --[[User:Jayron32|<span style="color:#009">Jayron</span>]][[User talk:Jayron32|<b style="color:#090">''32''</b>]] 16:31, 25 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant#rfc_19B925C|Talk:Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] expired 2015-04-10 05:00 ===
* Id: 19B925C
* User: GregKaye
* Date: 2015-03-14 12:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|651331595|HIST 651331595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|651331599|POL 651331599}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|651331602|RELI 651331602}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|651331604|SOC 651331604}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|655785351|HIST 655785351}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|655785353|POL 655785353}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|655785356|RELI 655785356}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|655785362|SOC 655785362}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Content that has, at various times,  previously been included in "Ideologies" section of the infobox include:  
*Sunni Islam/Sunni Islamism, Anti-Shiaism[5], Extremist Islamism, Fascism, Salafism, Salafist Jihadism, Takfirism, Wahhabism 
''(and these entries represent all the content that I have found when trawling through the article's revision history).''

Results (which just mean that sets of wording happen to be found in some way on the same pages) relating to this content are as follows:
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+OR+isis+OR+daesh+OR+%22islamic+state%22)+and+%22Fascism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Fascism"] got "About 1,180,000 results"
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+OR+isis+OR+daesh+OR+%22islamic+state%22)+and+%22wahhabism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Wahhabism"] got "About 153,000 results"
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil%20or%20isis%20or%20daesh%20or%20%22islamic%20state%22)%20and%20%22sunni%20islam%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Sunni Islam"] got "About 27,200 results" 
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+or+isis+or+daesh+or+%22islamic+state%22)+AND+%22Salafism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Salafism"] got "About 13,900 results" 
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+or+isis+or+daesh+or+%22islamic+state%22)+AND+%22Takfirism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Takfirism"] got "About 11,500 results" 
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+or+isis+or+daesh+or+%22islamic+state%22)+AND+%22Salafist+jihadism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Salafist jihadism"] got "About 1,430 results" 
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+or+isis+or+daesh+or+%22islamic+state%22)+AND+%22Sunni+Islamism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Sunni Islamism"] got "About 270 results" 
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+or+isis+or+daesh+or+%22islamic+state%22)+AND+%22Anti-Shiaism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Anti-Shiaism"] got "About 192 results" 
*[https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=(isil+or+isis+or+daesh+or+%22islamic+state%22)+AND+%22Extremist+Islamism%22 (isil or isis or daesh or "islamic state") AND "Extremist Islamism"] got "About 198 results" 

At most recent edit the ideologies were edited to/down to:
*Salafist jihadism
*Salafism[6][7]
Editor comment would be welcome on this but I '''suggest''' that a content might be:
* [[Sunni Islam]]
* [[Salafism]]/[[Wahhabism]]
* [[Takfirism]]
I also provisionally think that the selectivity of "facism" has a great relevance, so also:
* [[Facism]]

I think that justification for inclusion of "Salafism" may be weak.  I don't think that there is justification for inclusion of "Salafist Jihadism" which is a neologism and which, in any case, seems to me to be synonymous with "Salafism" and "Wahhabism".  Despite the fact that one of the clear drives within the group has been to engage with proponent of Shia Islam, I don't think that a reference to Anti-Shiaism is supported.  However, given the context of its religious cleansing and persecution of people who do not share the groups Sunni based philosophies, I think that a reference to "Sunni Islam" is warranted.

I thought to raise the subject here to hopefully protect the content from [[wp:tendentious]] editing.  If it is possible to establish the relevance of the ideologies here I don't see that there would be relevance of including source references to the content in the article.  The validity of one of the ideological references is not increased because an editor has found that a particular source has made that reference to the group.

Here are notifications to/of contributory editors
*{{Ping|Nulla Taciti}} removed <nowiki>[[Takfirism]] and [[Anti-Shi'ism|Anti-Shiaism]]</nowiki> in Revision as of 20:30, 16 January 2015
*{{Ping|Imfeelyoung}} changed  <nowiki>[[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] [[Islamism]]<br />[[Wahhabi|Salafism]] → [[Extremist]] [[Islamism]]<br />[[Wahhabi]]<br/>[[Salafist Jihadism]]</nowiki> in Revision as of 10:09, 23 January 2015
*{{Ping|Ritsaiph}} removed <nowiki> [[Extremist]] [[Islamism]]</nowiki> in Revision as of 01:36, 11 February 2015
*{{Ping|Mbcap}} added <nowiki>[[Salafism]]<ref name="NS">...</nowiki> in Revision as of 19:11, 15 February 2015
*{{Ping|Fraytel}} added <nowiki>[[Fascism]] <ref>...</nowiki> in Revision as of 19:30, 21 February 2015
*{{Ping|KahnJohn27}} removed <nowiki>[[Wahhabism]]<ref>...<br />...[[Fascism]] <ref>..</nowiki> in Revision as of 12:21, 22 February 2015
*{{Ping|Vietcong nuturlizer}} changed <nowiki>[[Salafism]] → [[Wahhabism]]</nowiki> in Revision as of 22:28, 22 February 2015
*{{Ping|Mbcap}} changed <nowiki>[[Wahhabism]] → [[Salafism]]</nowiki> in Revision as of 22:53, 22 February 2015
[[User:GregKaye|Greg]][[User talk:GregKaye|Kaye]] 12:27, 14 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Words to watch#rfc_53C495B|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Words to watch]] expired 2015-04-11 10:00 ===
* Id: 53C495B
* User: GregKaye
* Date: 2015-03-16 11:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|651622728|HIST 651622728}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|651622734|RELI 651622734}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|656595827|HIST 656595827}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|656595832|RELI 656595832}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Propose''' adding myth and mythology to the content on "words to watch" in [[WP:LABEL]] in regard to all uses of the word.  I don't intend by this that the words be excluded from use but just, if alternative presentations can be given, then these should be considered.  This is in line with the general spirit of the article which begins with the text: "There are [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia is not censored|no forbidden words or expressions on Wikipedia]], but certain expressions should be used with care, because they may introduce bias."  

At present the text of [[WP:LABEL]] begins, "[[Value-laden]] labels ... may express contentious opinion and are best avoided unless widely used by reliable sources to describe the subject, in which case use [[WP:INTEXT|in-text attribution]]."

In the thread immediately above I have suggested that this can read, "[[Value-laden]] labels ... may express contentious opinion and [''may be''] best avoided unless widely used by reliable sources to describe the subject, in which case use [[WP:INTEXT|in-text attribution]]."

This proposal follows a long discussion at: [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Religion#Disambiguations of divinities]] in which continued and unanimous opposition was given to the use of the disambiguation "... (mythology)".

The problem here is perceived [[WP:SYSTEMICBIAS]] in which present day faiths seem to be automatically classified as "religions", "faiths" etc. while previously practised faiths get regularly classified as "myths" and "mythologies".  Words like "folklore" regularly don't even get a look in.  My contention is that practitioners of present day religions have established bias by being instrumental in developing the description of prior forms of belief as myth.  

According to the online Oxford dictionary definition of: [http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/myth myth,] there seems to be no major problem with the first definition.  
:1. A traditional story, especially one concerning the early history of a people or explaining a natural or social phenomenon, and typically involving supernatural beings or events:
If this was viewed in isolation there might be no problem as the word might be considered to neutrally present a ''narrative'' on a religious theme.  I am not sure when or how the second definition definition was developed/was first used but I consider this to present the problem.
:2. A widely held but false belief or idea:
The result, I think, is that present day religions are falsely differentiated from previous faiths.  

I think that the problem here goes far beyond a mere [[Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Expressions_of_doubt|#Expression of doubt]] but that the usage goes as far as to [[WP:ASSERT]] falsity when the same stance is not adopted with present day faiths.  See the articles [[Creation myth]] (which I am not necessarily arguing against) and [[Genesis creation narrative]] for examples of this.  

A positive way forward I think would be actions such as to favour links such articles as [[Ancient Greek religion]] as opposed to [[Greek mythology]].  This, I think, would reduce current discrepancy.

I will notify the religion and mythology wikiprojects of this discussion.  [[User:GregKaye|Greg]][[User talk:GregKaye|Kaye]] 11:47, 16 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Words to watch#rfc_1227AD0|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Words to watch]] expired 2015-04-11 10:00 ===
* Id: 1227AD0
* User: GregKaye
* Date: 2015-03-12 09:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|651617766|POL 651617766}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|655951755|POL 655951755}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
RfC added on 16 March
*Regarding the discussion above I suggest that an additional shortcut be added to this section as: [[WP:W2WTERRORIST]] which would then change the listing of shortcuts for the section to read: [[WP:LABEL]] [[WP:TERRORIST]] [[WP:W2WTERRORIST]].
*Changing the text from saying "Value-laden labels ... are best avoided" to saying "Value-laden labels ... may be best avoided" 
*Changing the title from "Contentious labels" to "Descriptions that can be used as contentious labels"
My view is that this section (in a content on a page entitled "words to watch" and which begins with the statement "There are [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia is not censored|no forbidden words or expressions on Wikipedia]]") is unnecessarily and unhelpfully proscriptive.  It is also contradictory saying that there are no forbidden words and then labelling a certain set of adjectives as "labels" and stating that they are best avoided.  For instance I would have no problem in describing, say, Nazi philosophy and motivations as being "racist".  In a slightly more contentious topic there is currently a discussion at [[Talk:ISIL]] on the use of the use of the widely used description "extremist" in the lead.  In other cases I think that various topics might be described as fundamentalist without any form of slur being offered.  In fact in some cases, and depending on the nature of the true fundamentals of the topic, this particular wording might well present them in an unrepresentationally favourable light.  In the specific title [[The Beatles (terrorist cell)]] I think that its least problematic part is the terrorist reference.  The four individuals concerned are not [[The Beatles]] and there is no evidence that I know of that the four of them act as an individual cell and on this basis I have requested an article move to the title [[ISIL militants nicknamed the Beatles]] with discussion [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:The_Beatles_(terrorist_cell)#Requested_move_7_March_2015 here.]  Otherwise I think that the terrorist description is arguably very apt as, to my interpretation, it has been the videoed [[Killing of captives by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|killing of captives]] including aid workers that largely substantiated ISIL's international designations as a terrorist organization.  

I think that it is very fair that the words mentioned be categorised as "words to watch" but I think that it would be wrong to be prescriptive in our approach.  My worry though is that, in a minority of cases, we may lose our ability to give pithy descriptions of topics.  Our main priority is to build an informative [[encyclopaedia]] and, IMO, not necessarily to pander to any [[politically correct]] agenda.  [[User:GregKaye|Greg]][[User talk:GregKaye|Kaye]] 09:33, 12 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Help talk:Referencing for beginners#rfc_FD6B3BE|Help talk:Referencing for beginners]] expired 2015-04-12 17:00 ===
* Id: FD6B3BE
* User: Moxy
* Date: 2015-03-13 16:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|651213826|UNSORTED 651213826}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|656143287|UNSORTED 656143287}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What type of sources manner should be explained first for our new editors-  "Manual referencing"  or "Using refToolbar"  

'''Comments '''

*'''Manual referencing''' should be first as per all the other intro pages to referencing <small>( [[Help:Introduction to referencing/1]] - [[Help:Footnotes]] - [[Wikipedia:Tutorial/Citing sources]] - [[Wikipedia:Inline citation]]  - [[Wikipedia:Citation templates]] and [[Wikipedia:Contributing to Wikipedia]] )</small>. We should not assume all our editors can support JavaScript. Plus making our new editors watch a 5 mins video or have to read  6 or 7  steps is simply not easier then telling them to  add  {{tag|ref|content=freetext}}. We should mention the method most used first. I personally think the  refToolbar is great but as a contributor to the help desks.....I see that refToolbar is another thing people have to learn. I believe knowing the very basics first is more helpful in the long run over telling new editors to use templates  that need to be filled out. Wikipedia permits editors to use any citation system that allows the reader to understand where the information came from. We should not assume all like the tools and will use them off the bat....we should give  the basic info first.... by telling people what the code looks..and where it can be found...then talk about the tools and other methods available.  Leavening people in the dark about what the code looks like and does is not helpful in the long run. People dont need to learn all the  HTML code just {{tag|ref|content=}} before they learn more . As of now we  talk about  how with refToolbar editors should remove the reftags for a bib before we even explain what the code is for...again putting the the cart before the horse.  -- [[User:Moxy|Moxy]] ([[User talk:Moxy|talk]]) 16:07, 13 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Littleton, Colorado#rfc_466F54B|Talk:Littleton, Colorado]] expired 2015-04-12 20:00 ===
* Id: 466F54B
* User: FUBAR007
* Date: 2015-03-13 19:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|651236210|HIST 651236210}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|656166924|HIST 656166924}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
An anonymous user, or possibly a small group of anonymous users, has repeatedly deleted the paragraph discussing the 1999 [[Columbine High School massacre]] that occurred near Littleton from this page's History section. Going by their edit summaries, it appears they feel that referencing the incident somehow promotes it.

I disagree, and I think the paragraph on the shootings should remain. Although the incident technically occurred in neighboring [[Columbine, Colorado]] (which has a Littleton ZIP code), it did draw national attention to Littleton and is thus relevant to the Littleton page's History section. To be fair, the paragraph in question has no citation.

I didn't author the reference to the shootings, but I am concerned that allowing its deletion on the grounds that it irritates another editor would set a bad precedent.

So, in the interest of defusing an edit war, I'm requesting comment from the editor community:  should the paragraph referencing the Columbine shootings remain in the Littleton article or not? [[User:FUBAR007|FUBAR007]] ([[User talk:FUBAR007|talk]]) 19:40, 13 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[User talk:Valoem/Involuntary celibacy#rfc_0EE79DA|User talk:Valoem/Involuntary celibacy]] expired 2015-04-14 20:00 ===
* Id: 0EE79DA
* User: Valoem/Involuntary celibacy#rfc_0EE79DA
* Date: 2015-03-15 19:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|651527199|MEDIA 651527199}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|651527204|SOC 651527204}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|656493876|MEDIA 656493876}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|656493888|SOC 656493888}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
:{{pagelinks|User:Valoem/Involuntary celibacy}} – (<includeonly>[[User talk:Valoem/Involuntary celibacy|View RFC/AfD]]</includeonly><noinclude>[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2015 March 31#{{anchorencode:User talk:Valoem/Involuntary celibacy}}|View log]]</noinclude>{{int:dot-separator}} <span class="plainlinks">[https://tools.wmflabs.org/jackbot/snottywong/cgi-bin/votecounter.cgi?page=User_talk:Valoem/Involuntary_celibacy Stats]</span>)
:({{Find sources AFD|Involuntary celibacy}}))
'''History'''
*[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Involuntary celibacy]] - keep
*[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Involuntary celibacy (2nd nomination)]] - merge
*[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Denise Donnelly]] - del
*[[Wikipedia:Deletion review/Log/2014 December 7]] - NC to restore

I've noticed a growing trend on Wikipedia which diverges from our initial goals with a dangerous precedence being set. Our goal is to document the world based on verfiability and notability. It is here that we have the right to document the unusual apart from the usual with a neutral point of view. Mainstream acceptance has '''never''' been a requirement, while this social phenomenon is unusual to rare there are enough secondary reliable sources to deem it notable. I feel in many ways the previous close was against consensus. We have the term '''no consensus''' for a reason such as this case when there is no consensus. The ensuing dispute only emphasizes the lack of consensus.

Upon reviewing the sources, this topic has been covered both academically and by mainstream media including a documented shooting which the perpetrator directly specified incelism as a motivate. I've added an additional six citations to tokyogirl's version the argument that this lacks notability or is not a social condition simply does not hold. I am requesting that the current version be moved to the mainspace. [[User:Valoem|<font color="DarkSlateGray">'''Valoem'''</font>]] <sup>[[User talk:Valoem|'''<font color="blue">talk</font>''']]</sup> <sup>[[Special:Contributions/Valoem|'''<font color="Green">contrib</font>''']]</sup> 19:57, 15 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt episodes#rfc_67F6406|Talk:List of Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt episodes]] expired 2015-04-15 00:00 ===
* Id: 67F6406
* User: JSH-alive
* Date: 2015-04-07 15:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|655530298|MEDIA 655530298}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|655530324|STYLE 655530324}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|655530333|POLICY 655530333}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|656529071|MEDIA 656529071}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|656529072|STYLE 656529072}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|656529077|POLICY 656529077}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, this episode list shows what each episode title is making a reference to by providing a link to corresponding Wikipedia articles. But many will think that those blue links are directing to articles about each PSG episodes, and most will have no idea if the episode title is a reference to the Japanese title of the subject (like ''Help!'' and ''The Mummy''). Now, we have three options:
# Give an explanation at the "Aux1" field for each episode.
# Do it, instead at the end of episode description.
# Remove any kind of explanation about episode titles completely.
[[User:JSH-alive|JSH-alive]]/<sup>[[User talk:JSH-alive|talk]]/[[Special:Contributions/JSH-alive|cont]]/[[Special:Emailuser/JSH-alive|mail]]</sup> 15:33, 7 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Stephen Cambone#rfc_54BCF64|Talk:Stephen Cambone]] expired 2015-04-15 18:00 ===
* Id: 54BCF64
* Date: 2015-03-16 17:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|651663312|BIO 651663312}}

* User: Artw

{{rfcquote|text=
A side effect of substing the decline reason from {{tl|AFC submission/comments}} to the talk page notification is that the talk pages are now getting included in the "Category:AfC submissions declined as..." categories (since inclusion in those categories was done by {{tl|AFC submission/comments}}. [[User:Ahecht|Ahecht]] ([[User_talk:Ahecht|<span style="color:#FFF;background:#00f;display:inline-block;padding:1px 1px 0;vertical-align:-0.3em;line-height:1;font-size:62.5%;text-align:center;"><b>TALK<br />PAGE</b></span>]]) 23:57, 17 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of cities proper by population#rfc_6839F51|Talk:List of cities proper by population]] expired 2015-04-17 03:00 ===
* Id: 6839F51
* User: Navops47
* Date: 2015-03-18 02:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|651874370|POL 651874370}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|656845505|POL 656845505}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We appear to be at a deadlock of the definition of city proper within this article and the grounds for inclusion of some of the cities and data in it. This [[UNICEF]] document here: http://www.unicef.org/sowc2012/pdfs/SOWC-2012-DEFINITIONS.pdf simply defines a city proper as " The population living within the administrative boundaries of a city e.g [[Washington, D.C.]] because city boundaries do not regularly adapt to accommodate population increases, the concepts of Urban [[Agglomerations|Agglomeration]] or [[Metropolitan area|Metropolitan Area]] are often used to improve the comparability of measurements of city populations across countries and over time" UNICEF (2012), However different countries apply different definitions previous discussions as shown above included counter arguments  for including Chinese cities in the list based on this Chinese expert's views on the subject " [http://faculty.washington.edu/kwchan/ Professor Kam Wing Chan University of Washington] in the United States, who has made a career out of correcting people's exaggerated claims about Chinese population statistics, explains that what China calls a municipality or city is better understood as a province. Many of the 30 million people who are said to live in the city of Chongqing are actually agricultural workers living in a rural setting, in fact, he says, the area is so huge it's about the size of Austria. 'Doom and gloom' "And if you were to travel from the downtown area to some of the peripheral areas where those 30 million live, it might take a day or two because the road conditions are not that good. So, this cannot be possibly called a city. Because when we call a place a city the general understanding is that we're talking about a commuting zone." Professor Chan calculates that a more reasonable estimate of the urban population of Chongqing is six or seven million. The largest city in China is actually Shanghai. It is commonly thought to have a population of 20 million, but Professor Chan thinks 16 million is a better estimate. He says everyone just loves to think China's cities are bigger than they actually are. He has even had to correct fellow experts at a world conference on global megacities of the future".  

'''Possible ways to resolve this situation would involve either'''

* Cutting content so as to fit in with some agreed definition's for criteria inclusion which must take into account published experts views in this area at the moment the article solely rely's on one source.

--[[User:Navops47|Navops47]] ([[User talk:Navops47|talk]]) 02:19, 18 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Religion#rfc_FC31648|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Religion]] expired 2015-04-17 10:00 ===
* Id: FC31648
* User: GregKaye
* Date: 2015-03-18 09:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|651906756|HIST 651906756}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|656879769|HIST 656879769}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RfC was originally mistakenly started with notification only being made to the "Religion and philosophy" group.  It too a discussion that, in acknowledgement of a limited number of editors being contacted, unanimously dropped support for the ".. (mythology)" disambiguation.  Prior to the close of the RfC I made moves to ".. (deity)" with the intention of developing the lists (presented below) of articles potentially at issue so that further issues might be incorporated here.  Moves were contested at [[Wikipedia talk:Requested moves#Request to revert a whole bunch of undiscussed moves]] and, with the exception of a handful of titles presenting technical difficulties, 500 moves have been reverted.  I now hope that an appropriate route forward/stance on this issue can be developed.  [[User:GregKaye|Greg]][[User talk:GregKaye|Kaye]] 09:33, 18 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Shaygan Kheradpir#rfc_B1514B4|Talk:Shaygan Kheradpir]] expired 2015-04-17 21:00 ===
* Id: B1514B4

{{rfcquote|text=
Which version of the Lead should be used:
* [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shaygan_Kheradpir&oldid=651208698 This one] which includes claims that Kheradpir was one of the first to note the consumerization of IT.

* <b>Comment</b> As [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3AShaygan_Kheradpir&diff=650847910&oldid=650840474 previously stated], I have looked through the sources provided and have not found anything that directly supports the claim that he was one of the first to notice the consumerization of IT. === [[Talk:Deaths in 2015#rfc_4717A95|Talk:Deaths in 2015]] expired 2015-04-17 23:00 ===
* Id: 4717A95
* User: Frickeg
* Date: 2015-03-18 22:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|651980520|BIO 651980520}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|656965026|BIO 656965026}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should some titles, such as "Sir" or "Dame", be mentioned on "Deaths in..." pages, and pipelinked, or should everyone be listed by their article title? [[User:InedibleHulk|InedibleHulk]] [[User_Talk:InedibleHulk|(talk)]] 20:53, [[March 18]], [[2015]] (UTC)

*'''Article titles only''' To hold those in the <s>peerage</s> whatever it is to a different standard from other titled people (medical, military, religious) is unfair. [[User:InedibleHulk|InedibleHulk]] [[User_Talk:InedibleHulk|(talk)]] 20:55, [[March 18]], [[2015]] (UTC)
*'''Mention "Sir" and "Dame"''' These are actually a different situation to medical, military and religious titles (except for "Pope", obviously). Almost all texts, especially those concerned with history, will refer to these titles as part of the person's name. This has been a long-standing distinction. (Note: knights and dames are not part of the peerage.) [[User:Frickeg|Frickeg]] ([[User talk:Frickeg|talk]]) 22:27, 18 March 2015 (UTC)}}

What in the world? Canadian-American is not an 'ethnicity.' 'Canadian and American is unnecessary,' Canadian-American is used to describe people with dual citizenship OR of descent. In this case, it's obviously citizenship and the 'and' is repetitive and unnecessary. Either way, 'Canadian' and 'American' aren't ethnicities, they're nationalities.[[User:Ladysif|Ladysif]] ([[User talk:Ladysif|talk]]) 04:27, 10 April 2015 (UTC)}}

* Id: A3F3CBF

{{rfcquote|text=
== Category:Prosperity theologians '''

'''Delete category'''

*Since Osteen has specifically denied being a prosperity theologian, which is explained in the article, he should not be placed in [[:Category:Prosperity theologians]]. We already include a mention of this controversy, with plenty of wikilinks. This is a policy issue. [[WP:CAT/R]]. We should not expect people to file an OTRS just to have something like that addressed, that is an unrealistic and bureaucratic expectation. === [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_79C60E9|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2015-04-19 03:00 ===
* Id: 79C60E9
* User: Valoem
* Date: 2015-04-05 20:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|655610873|STYLE 655610873}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|656529077|POLICY 656529077}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|657130911|STYLE 657130911}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|657130915|POLICY 657130915}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been a recent shift toward moving professional esports players name to their "gamer tag". I believe this to be both inefficient and improper. A guideline needs to be established so that all esports players should be listed under common birth name for two primary reasons:

*Players can change their gamer tags
*Players may choose inappropriate tags or name which they may regret.

The second issue is same names for esports players should be label (electronic sports player) instead of (professional gamer) as the latter can refer to [[gambling]] as well. [[User:Valoem|<font color="DarkSlateGray">'''Valoem'''</font>]] <sup>[[User talk:Valoem|'''<font color="blue">talk</font>''']]</sup> <sup>[[Special:Contributions/Valoem|'''<font color="Green">contrib</font>''']]</sup> 20:30, 5 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Tree of Life#rfc_51571B9|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Tree of Life]] expired 2015-04-19 17:00 ===
* Id: 51571B9
* User: SPACKlick
* Date: 2015-03-20 16:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|652755765|BIO 652755765}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|652755768|SCI 652755768}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|657205924|BIO 657205924}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|657205925|SCI 657205925}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have noticed some contradictions on and across several pages relating to the taxonomic classification of Chimpanzees. In essence some pages use the system where Homininae split into Gorillini and Hominini and then Hominini divides into Hominina and Panina. Other pages use a system where Homininae trifurcates into Gorillini, Hominini and Panini. Several pages use both in different Parts. (Chimpanzee lists Chimpanzees as Hominini in the lede but Panini in the infobox). I can't find sources detailing a controversy or an overturn of the historic system. Which should be used and can I get some help making the pages consistent?

Affected Pages:
[[Hominini]], [[Sahelanthropus]], [[Homininae]], [[Chimpanzee-human last common ancestor]], [[Ape]],
[[Hominidae]], [[Homo]], [[Chimpanzee]], [[Primate]], [[Homo Floresiensis#Bone structure]], [[Timeline of human evolution]], [[List of mammals of Burundi]], [[List of primates]], [[Human]], [[Panini]],[[Common Chimpanzee]], [[Bonobo]]

Also may be affected {{No redirect|Hominin}} and {{No redirect|Panini (primates)}}

Apologies if this is in the wrong place [[User:SPACKlick|SPACKlick]] ([[User talk:SPACKlick|talk]]) 16:34, 20 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bond girl#rfc_3BDDFDB|Talk:Bond girl]] expired 2015-04-20 18:00 ===
* Id: 3BDDFDB
* User: TheLastAmigo
* Date: 2015-03-21 17:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|652905927|MEDIA 652905927}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|657358856|MEDIA 657358856}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I believe that the criteria for what constitutes a Bond girl seems to be skirting awfully close to violating both the [[Wikipedia:No original research|WP:OR]] and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|WP:V]] rules. It is cited nowhere within the article that a Bond girl must be James Bond's love interest. The criteria that a Bond girl is only James Bond's love interest seems to be rather limiting because it would imply that the lead female character of ''[[Quantum of Solace (film)|Quantum of Solace]]'', [[Camille Montes]] played by [[Olga Kurylenko]], is not a Bond girl simply because her relationship with James Bond is platonic. I believe that there should be more citations from outside sources before we dictate that a Bond girl is ONLY a love interest of James Bond.[[User:TheLastAmigo|TheLastAmigo]] ([[User talk:TheLastAmigo|talk]]) 17:46, 21 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiBullying#rfc_F8D1055|Wikipedia talk:WikiBullying]] expired 2015-04-20 21:00 ===
* Id: F8D1055
* User: Flyer22
* Date: 2015-03-21 20:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|652926053|POLICY 652926053}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|652926058|PROJ 652926058}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|657383253|POLICY 657383253}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|657383258|PROJ 657383258}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
With regard to [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:WikiBullying&diff=652805957&oldid=652804431 this version] of the WP:Bully page, one argument is that the previous version has a clearer lead and the new version has a poor lead and misinterprets how parts of Wikipedia is supposed to work; the other argument is that the new version is "Some clean up of phrasing and structure but an IMPORTANT addition of Flippant content edits category of wikibully." For more details on this, see the short [[#Recent changes to the essay]] section above.  
 
On a side note: I clearly know that this is a [[WP:Essay]]; but since it states that the essay is "is intended to supplement the [[Wikipedia:Civility]] and [[Wikipedia:Ownership of articles]] policies, to which editors should defer in case of inconsistency between that page and this one," I tagged the WP:RfC with "rfc|policy" in addition to "rfc|proj." I tagged it with "rfc|pro" because the template also states "collaborations", and essays are similar to [[WP:WikiProjects]], and I didn't know what else to tag this WP:RfC with if not the "rfc|policy" and "rfc|proj" tags. [[User:Flyer22|Flyer22]] ([[User talk:Flyer22|talk]]) 20:35, 21 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Child sexual abuse#rfc_B801058|Talk:Child sexual abuse]] expired 2015-04-21 00:00 ===
* Id: B801058
* User: Flyer22
* Date: 2015-03-21 23:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|652945144|POL 652945144}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|652945151|SOC 652945151}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|657401825|POL 657401825}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|657401826|SOC 657401826}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
One view is that "[child molestation is not the same as child sexual abuse]. Child rape is also sexual abuse but not molestation.", and that "many references cover rape and penetration which is not molestation but still defined as sexual abuse. This article covers both rape & molestation." The other view is that "[i]t is the same thing, in various [[WP:Reliable sources]] and [[WP:MEDRS]]-compliant sources. It belongs per that and per [[WP:Alternative title]]. [The terms ''child sexual abuse'' and ''child molestation'' are commonly used interchangeably. The same goes for ''child sexual abuser'' and ''child molester.'']" For more commentary on this matter, see the [[#Child sexual abuse is not the same as molestation.]] section above. [[User:Flyer22|Flyer22]] ([[User talk:Flyer22|talk]]) 23:33, 21 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Chemistry#rfc_B1B9B6C|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Chemistry]] expired 2015-04-21 23:00 ===
* Id: B1B9B6C
* User: Kkmurray
* Date: 2015-03-22 22:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|653078148|SCI 653078148}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|653078155|STYLE 653078155}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|657889625|SCI 657889625}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|657889631|STYLE 657889631}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Article titles in [[:Category:Nuclear magnetic resonance]] are a mix of spelled out (e.g. [[nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy]]) and acronym (e.g. [[gradient enhanced NMR spectroscopy]]). The Manual of Style [[WP:ACRONYMTITLE]] says that "acronyms should be used in a page name if the subject is known primarily by its abbreviation and that abbreviation is primarily associated with the subject" and "if readers somewhat familiar with the subject are likely to only recognize the name by its acronym". Should NMR articles always use "NMR", always use "nuclear magnetic resonance", or should use be determined on a case-by-case basis? If case-by-case, what criteria should be used? --[[User:Kkmurray|Kkmurray]] ([[User talk:Kkmurray|talk]]) 22:28, 22 March 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:G. Edward Griffin#rfc_D2B97AC|Talk:G. Edward Griffin]] expired 2015-04-22 04:00 ===
* Id: D2B97AC
* Date: 2015-04-20 13:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|657329337|BIO 657329337}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|657329342|SCI 657329342}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|663261643|BIO 663261643}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|663261649|SCI 663261649}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Based on statements above, I think these are the points on which Atsme would like clarification:
# Is it accurate to characterise laetrile as quackery when there are clinics that use it? {{xt|There '''are treatments in use today''' so if medical practitioners are '''legally''' prescribing amygdalin as integrative therapy, why should WP assume the position that it's quackery based on journal articles that are 30+ years old?  [http://drmanso.com/patient-education-guide/cancer-plan-stress/], [http://www.doctorshealthpress.com/vitamin-b17-and-cancer] (about those doctors: [http://www.doctorshealthpress.com/meet-the-doctors])}}; {{xt|If it is quackery as what was stated in Wiki voice in the lead, why are the following medical centers allowed to use laetrile (amygdalin) as part of their prescribed integrative therapies?[http://www.biomedici.ca/protocols.html] [http://www.renointegrativemedicalcenter.example.com/laetrile.html].}}
# Does a statement on a page of the International Myeloma Foundation materially affect the status of laetrile as it should be reflected in this article? {{xt|Is the [[International Myeloma Foundation]] (June Pruitt) a RS? [http://myeloma.org/ArticlePage.action?articleId=419].}}
# Does the widespread use of laetrile invalidate the claim that is it quackery? {{xt| If the therapy itself is worthless quackery, why is it still being used around the world? [http://pdfsearch.usrs0.com/pdf/B17_Vitamins/Giuseppe_Nacci_M_D__Guida_Alla_Salute_Naturale_Di__/7_pdf\]}}
# Does current research on amygdalin invalidate the stated fact that laetrile is quackery? {{xt|If laetrile (amygdalin) is worthless quackery, why is there still ongoing academic and scientific research?  Read the guidelines in [[WP:FRINGE/PS]] before you answer that question, and see the following: [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25333694], [http://library.macewan.ca/library-search/detailed-view/rzh/2012726994?query=%28Zuoqing+Song%29], [http://www.labome.org/topics/chemicals/organic/nitriles/amygdalin-10515.html], [http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0100-879X2009000400006&script=sci_arttext], [http://www.spandidos-publications.com/mmr/7/5/1453].}}
# Does this constitute a reliable source refuting the claim that laetrile is quackery? {{xt|Why are RS still covering the issue 30+ years later? [http://www.wnyc.org/story/why-potentially-promising-experimental-cancer-therapy-was-kept-secret-and-how-it-was-exposed/]}}
# Does the date of the book's publication materially affect the characterisation of laetrile as portrayed in the book? {{xt|Considering the first publication date of the book, is there a reason to exclude information regarding the 60 Minutes broadcast in 1974 titled "Laetrile: Cure or quackery" with Mike Wallace? [http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/1974-laetrile-cure-or-quackery/]}}
Some of this is redundant to the ongoing RfC, in which consensus seems reasonably clear to me, but these are further, specific questions on which it seems reasonable to seek closure. <b>[[User Talk:JzG|Guy]]</b> <small>([[User:JzG/help|Help!]])</small> 13:04, 20 April 2015 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|658588313|POL 658588313}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|658588336|SOC 658588336}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{ping|I dream of horses|Byronmercury|Amatulic|Hugetim|Warko|Unbuttered Parsnip|Y-S.Ko|Hendrick 99}} How to improve article navigation, what to remove and what to keep?

I have brought this to RfC because I think we need a methodical way to improve the navigation of the article. Ways of improving navigation include-

* Removal of sections
* Making sections more concise
* Grouping sections into general themes (currently there are about 42 main headings in the article)

If we are removing and grouping its good to use references to guide us. I've found two candidates, are there any others?


* [https://web.archive.org/web/20110629230810/http://www.newschool.edu/nssr/het/ New School] 

{{collapse|2=New School groupings (four headings, each with two subheadings)|
#Schools of Political Economy
##Pre-Classical	
##Classical
#Neoclassical Schools	
##Anglo-American	
##Continental
#Alternative Schools	
##Heterodox	
##Keynesian
#Thematic Schools
##Themes
##Other
}}
