=== [[Talk:The Federalist (website)#rfc_BE6D798|Talk:The Federalist (website)]] expired 2015-05-22 17:00 ===
* Id: BE6D798
* Date: 2015-04-22 16:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|658533454|MEDIA 658533454}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|658533456|POL 658533456}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|663564292|MEDIA 663564292}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|663564296|POL 663564296}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This material was deleted under arguments of [[WP:COATRACK]], and [[WP:POV]]. Are any of these concerns substantive to warrant non-inclusion? 

{{talkquote|An article published in ''Politico Magazine'', titled "The HuffPo-ization of the Right" describes a number of [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] websites and online publications, including  ''The Federalist'', ''[[The Daily Caller]]'', ''[[Weekly Standard]]'', ''[[Breitbart (website)|Breitbart]]'', and ''[[The Blaze]]''.<ref name=PM.HuffPo/> Cherlin refers to targeted sites like the ''[[Washington Free Beacon]]'' and ''The Federalist'' as "seek[ing] to go deep on the issues and sway the conversation in Washington." In the article, Cherlin mentions that conservatives appreciate the new range of right-wing outlets, including Domenech’s claim that "[t]he only thing that I think is hurtful to the movement is if you didn’t have that kind of variety". The article reports that the focus of these right-wing outlets is on hardening opposition to President [[Barack Obama]], with a view beyond the end of his second term.  Domenech goes on to compare such focus with the proliferation of liberal outlets at a similar point during President [[George W. Bush]]’s tenure.<ref name=PM.HuffPo>{{cite web|title=The HuffPo-ization of the Right|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/01/conservative-media-huffpo-ization-of-the-right-101877_Page2.html#ixzz3F64NsJoS|publisher=Politico Magazine|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref>{{reflist talk}}}}

''' Comments '''

* '''Support inclusion''' - It provides context to the appearance of ''The Federalist''in the conservative media landscape, and refers to Ben Domenech, co-founder of ''The Federalist'',  who was interviewed for this piece. -  [[User:Cwobeel|<span style="color:#339966">Cwobeel</span>]] [[User_talk:Cwobeel|<span style="font-size:80%">(talk)</span>]] 16:20, 22 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Beepi#rfc_5168262|Talk:Beepi]] expired 2015-05-22 21:00 ===
* Id: 5168262
* User: BC1278
* Date: 2015-04-22 20:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|657070323|ECON 657070323}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|663591996|ECON 663591996}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{request edit}}

''' Add new info on Beepi '''

Disclosure: [[WP: COI]] I have a COI. Please see my user profile, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:BC1278,  for a fuller disclosure and my affirmation that I abide by all Wikipedia policies and put the Wikipedia mission above other considerations. 

Three major stories appeared about Beepi appeared April, 2015, one in The New York Times, Bloomberg Business Week, one in USA Today. <ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-08/beepi-sees-valuation-soaring-with-revenue-in-national-expansion|title =Beepi Expands Reach of Service That’s Like Zappos for Used Cars|last = Cao|first = Jing|date = April 8, 2015|work = Bloomberg Business Week|access-date = April 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/04/07/beepi-aims-for-uber-like-ease-buying-and-selling-used-cars/25421887/|title =Beepi brings Uber-like ease to used-car shopping|last = della Cava|first = Marco|date = April 8, 2015|work = USA Today|access-date = April 13, 2015}}</ref>

From Business Week we learned the Beepi's revenue has grown 10x since December 2014, since it raised $79 million. <ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-08/beepi-sees-valuation-soaring-with-revenue-in-national-expansion|title =Beepi Expands Reach of Service That’s Like Zappos for Used Cars|last = Cao|first = Jing|date = April 8, 2015|work = Bloomberg Business Week|access-date = April 13, 2015}}</ref>

The New York Times reported the Beepi revenue is expected to be $100 million over the next year. <ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/23/technology/personaltech/an-online-tune-up-for-the-used-car-marketplace.html?hpw&rref=business&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=well-region&region=bottom-well&WT.nav=bottom-well|title =An Online Tune-Up for the Used-Car Marketplace|last =Manjoo|first = Farhad|date = April 22, 2015|work = The New York Times|access-date = April 22, 2015}}</ref>

I think these facts should be added to the article as it's highly relevant to any reader researching the economic performance of the company and the peer-to-peer online marketplace business model. 

Then on April, 15 2015, Forbes named Beepi to their list of companies expected to reach a billion dollar valuation. It says the company currently has a $200 million valuation. <ref>{{Cite news|url =
http://www.forbes.com/pictures/feki45efiei/beepi/ |title =Next Billion Dollar Start Ups: Beepi|last =|first =|date = April 15, 2015|work = Forbes|access-date = April 18, 2015}}</ref>

I'd also like to add a sentence to the this article based on this, as I think it's highly relevant to the subject matter and will be of great interest to anyone trying to learn about this company. The source, Fobres Magazine, is highly reputable as an independent media company. 

The complete suggested edit is:

Beepi's revenue has grown 10x since December 2014, since it raised $79 million <ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-08/beepi-sees-valuation-soaring-with-revenue-in-national-expansion|title =Beepi Expands Reach of Service That’s Like Zappos for Used Cars|last = Cao|first = Jing|date = April 8, 2015|work = Bloomberg Business Week|access-date = April 13, 2015}}</ref> and is on track to reach $100 million annually, the company reported. <ref>{{Cite news|url =http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/23/technology/personaltech/an-online-tune-up-for-the-used-car-marketplace.html?hpw&rref=business&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=well-region&region=bottom-well&WT.nav=bottom-well|title =An Online Tune-Up for the Used-Car Marketplace|last =Manjoo|first = Farhad|date = April 22, 2015|work = The New York Times|access-date = April 22, 2015}}</ref> In April 2015, [[Forbes]] named Beepi to their list of companies expected to reach a billion dollar valuation. It says the company currently has a $200 million valuation. <ref>{{Cite news|url =
http://www.forbes.com/pictures/feki45efiei/beepi/ |title =Next Billion Dollar Start Ups: Beepi|last =|first =|date = April 15, 2015|work = Forbes|access-date = April 18, 2015}}</ref>

Comments? Suggested edit? Would anyone like to add it? Thank you. 

[[User:BC1278|BC1278]] ([[User talk:BC1278|talk]]) 20:51, 22 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Contra Adventure#rfc_D52025A|Talk:The Contra Adventure]] expired 2015-05-24 04:00 ===
* Id: D52025A
* User: Terminegen
* Date: 2015-05-19 03:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|663034011|SCI 663034011}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|663034017|MEDIA 663034017}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|663754341|SCI 663754341}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|663754344|MEDIA 663754344}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Foreword: as the section's title indicates, this matter is completely irrelevant to the title of this Wikipedia article.

The concern right now involves the correct title of this video game. One position is C: The Contra Adventure, the other is simply The Contra Adventure. The latter is supported only by the assumption that the large "C" in the game's packaging case and manual is nothing more than a "logogram" and not part of the actual name.

There is weighted evidence that supports the notion that the official name of this video game is C: The Contra Adventure. Here is a sample of reputable sources, out of a pool of several:

:http://ca.ign.com/articles/1998/09/17/c-the-contra-adventure
:http://www.amazon.com/C-Contra-Adventure-Playstation/dp/B00002STIG
:http://www.gamefaqs.com/ps/196860-c-the-contra-adventure
:http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0782031/
:http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/c-the-contra-adventure-review/1900-2546981/
:http://contra.wikia.com/wiki/C_-_The_Contra_Adventure
:http://strategywiki.org/wiki/C:_The_Contra_Adventure
:http://www.giantbomb.com/c-the-contra-adventure/3030-7454/
:http://klustr.net/contra/games/
:https://contrapedia.wordpress.com/c-the-contra-adventure/
:http://contra.kontek.net/games/games.htm

Further, the other games in the Contra series have a similar design to the name on their packaging:

:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contra_III:_The_Alien_Wars
:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contra:_Hard_Corps
:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contra:_Legacy_of_War
:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contra:_Shattered_Soldier
:http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_Corps:_Uprising

They are universally and unanimously accepted as having the colon and the text that precedes it in the official title.

The strongest evidence that supports the title of C: The Contra Adventure is present directly in the video game's instruction manual, on several pages:

:http://i.imgur.com/omsJPjm.jpg
:http://i.imgur.com/tXc3J0n.jpg
:http://i.imgur.com/2Tr2ySt.jpg
:http://i.imgur.com/ON39M6v.jpg
[[User:Terminegen|Terminegen]] ([[User talk:Terminegen|talk]]) 03:53, 19 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Requests for comment#rfc_D0F5222|Wikipedia talk:Requests for comment]] expired 2015-05-25 13:00 ===
* Id: D0F5222

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How much control may an RFC originator exert over the discussion? Is it appropriate (or should it be so) to actively prohibit alternatives from being proposed by other users and debated in the same discussion? The RFC guidance is silent on the subject of ownership. —[[Special:Contributions/174.141.182.82|174.141.182.82]] ([[User talk:174.141.182.82|talk]]) 12:56, 25 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_2C94743|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2015-05-25 20:00 ===
* Id: 2C94743
* Date: 2015-05-14 05:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|662670559|STYLE 662670559}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|666723826|STYLE 666723826}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Because the proposal to establish a dedicated [[Wikipedia:Village_pump_(proposals)/Archive_122#Proposal:_creation_of_.22style_noticeboard.22|style noticeboard]] has fallen through, it is now proposed that Wikipedia talk:MoS be established as Wikipedia's official page for style Q&A.  This would involve the following actions:

:1) Adding text to the effect of "and for questions about the use of capitalization, punctuation, organization and other matters of style on Wikipedia" to "This is the talk page for discussing improvements to the Manual of Style page."
:2) Inserting text to the effect of "ask style questions at Wikipedia talk:MoS" any place that would otherwise have pointed to a style noticeboard.
:3) Inserting text to the effect of "ask style questions at Wikipedia talk:MoS (and not here)" in the talk pages of other style guide pages so that style Q&A is more centralized.

Here are the kinds of questions that people ask: [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style#question_about_tense_for_historic_aircraft|1]], [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Archive_104#I_need_advice_on_how_to_start_a_sentence|2]], [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Archive_165#Possible_WP:ENGVAR_issue.3F|3]].

The goal of this proposal is make help with Wikipedia style issues easier to find and more centralized without increasing opportunities for forum shopping.  WT: MoS has already served as an unofficial Q&A board for many years.  The discussion leading up to this proposal is available [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Archive_165#Details_for_making_WT:MoS_the_official_page_for_style_questions|here]]. 05:06, 14 May 2015 (UTC)}}

*To me,  "actor, singer, writer, producer, director, comedian, and television host" seems long-winded, and "entertainer" feels more appropriate as it could be elaborated upon further on in the article. "Unite the Magic" is labeled "Episode 1", and [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Otnwyl3Cw-4?t=23m41s an annotation at the end of the YouTube version of the video says "Episode 2 Coming Soon"] (as of late April 2015), so I thought it's going to be a series of 20-something-minute television episodes. === [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (definite or indefinite article at beginning of name)#rfc_12675BB|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (definite or indefinite article at beginning of name)]] expired 2015-05-26 16:00 ===
* Id: 12675BB
* User: GregKaye
* Date: 2015-04-26 15:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|659309430|STYLE 659309430}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|664135469|STYLE 664135469}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
To save giving up on this I thought I'd have a go with an RfC.

This comes after the compilation and presentation of a number of extensive multiple RMs which, while gaining limited support, have otherwise been shot down in flames.  I do not, however, consider this to be forum shopping as various of the less positive contributors have commented that the presentation of an RfC would be an appropriate route to take.  Base pages for the current multiple RfC are as follows:
*[[List of largest airlines in Africa]] → [[List of the largest airlines in Africa]]
*[[List of most common surnames in Asia]] → [[List of the most common surnames in Asia]]
*[[List of tallest bridges in the world]] → [[List of the tallest bridges in the world]]
*[[List of world's largest passenger ships]] → [[List of the world's largest passenger ships]]
At personal preference I think that it would be beneficial if a decision can be made one way or another on this topic before the closure of the RMs so as to, potentially, save the effort that went into their compilation.

On the basis that Wikipedia is an encyclopedia I conducted a search on books in the form: [https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#tbm=bks&q=(most+OR+least+OR+lightest+OR+heaviest+OR+tallest+OR+longest+OR+shortest)+AND+%22in+the%22 (most OR least OR lightest OR heaviest OR tallest OR longest OR shortest) AND "in the".]  Results that contained a "fooest" content followed by something like an "in bar" content were, in sequence, as follows:
{{Ordered list
|The Most Beautiful Girl in the World
|The Most Misused Verses in the Bible
|The Most Important Fish in the Sea
|The Most Dangerous Area in the World
|The 100 Most Significant Events in American Business
|The Most Wonderful Doll in the World
|The Most Dangerous Man In The World
|The Most Important Little Boy in the World
|Vesuvius: The most famous volcano in the world
|The tallest, shortest, longest, greenest, brownest animal in the jungle!
|The Most Successful Small Business in The World
|Burj Khalifa: The Tallest Tower in the World
|The Least Examined Branch: The Role of Legislatures in the Constitutional State
|A short synopsis of the most essential points in Hawaiian grammar
|A brief summary, in plain language, of the most important laws of England concerning women
|Catalonia: An Emerging Economy : the Most Cost-effective Ports in the Mediterranean Sea
|The Politics of the Governed: Reflections on Popular Politics ''in Most of the World''
|The Most Powerful Idea in the World: A Story of Steam,..
|Notices of the Most Remarkable Fires in Edinburgh
|''Most'' Beautiful House in the World
}}
I went through 18+ examples (not including, presumably, reprints or the "in Most of the World" example) that consistently used "the fooest" before finding one example, which happened to be at the beginning of the phrasing, which omitted the article.  


My next step in research involved a web based search on [https://www.google.co.uk/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=grammar%20guide%20superlative grammar guide superlative]

Results (with quotation of sections of relevant content) in sequence are presented as follows:

http://esl.fis.edu/grammar/rules/comp.htm  presenting:

'''1-syllable adjectives:''' add -'''est''' to the adjective (plus ''the'')

*My sister is '''the tallest''' in our family.
*Yesterday was '''the coldest''' day of the year so far.
... and so on

https://learnenglish.britishcouncil.org/en/english-grammar/adjectives/comparative-and-superlative-adjectives presenting:
*{{green|'''Superlative adjectives:'''}}
:We use '''''the''''' with a superlative:

:It was {{Underline|'''the happiest'''}} day of my life.
:Everest is {{Underline|'''the highest'''}} mountain in the world.
:That’s {{Underline|'''the best'''}} film I have seen this year.
:I have three sisters, Jan is {{Underline|'''the oldest'''}} and Angela is {{Underline|'''the youngest'''}}.

http://www.edufind.com/english-grammar/comparative-and-superlative/ presenting:

<big>SUPERLATIVE ADJECTIVES</big>

Superlative adjectives are used to describe an object which is at the upper or lower limit of a quality (''the tallest, the smallest, the fastest, the highest''). They are used in sentences where a subject is compared to a group of objects.

Noun (subject) + verb + the + superlative adjective + noun (object).

'''The group that is being compared with can be omitted if it is clear from the context (final example below).'''

EXAMPLES

*My house is the '''largest''' one in our neighborhood.
*This is the '''smallest''' box I've ever seen.
*Your dog ran the '''fastest''' of any dog in the race.
*We all threw our rocks at the same time. My rock flew the '''highest'''. ("of all the rocks" is understood)

This text is as presented on the website and represents basic grammar.

The fourth website - http://www.learnenglish.de/grammar/adjectivesuper.html - shows that even the Germans get this right.  Why can't we???


My concern is that, at present, Wikipedia presents examples of use of syntax that, if students were to emulate, would lose them marks.  

I have also seen nothing similar to the current Wikipedia title presentations in contents like Britannica.  


Many list type articles that contain superlatives are linked to [[:Category:Lists of superlatives]]

[[User:GregKaye|Greg]][[User talk:GregKaye|Kaye]] 15:15, 26 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_D8308C5|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2015-05-26 17:00 ===
* Id: D8308C5
* User: The ed17
* Date: 2015-04-26 16:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|659316596|HIST 659316596}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|660613123|POLICY 660613123}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|660613131|PROP 660613131}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|664143986|HIST 664143986}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|664144003|POLICY 664144003}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|664144008|PROP 664144008}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[File:Uss nevada.jpg|thumb|300px|right|TLDR: as a general reader, what seems easier to you: {{USS|Nevada|BB-36}} or [[USS Nevada (BB-36)|USS ''Nevada'' (1914)]]?]]
This RfC proposes to replace [[Hull number|hull]] or [[pennant number|pennant]] numbers in article titles with [[Ceremonial ship launching|launch dates]]. As my views have previously been made [[Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Military_history/Archive_129#On_hull.2Fpennant_numbers|abundantly clear]], I'll present them here. 

:Currently, Wikipedia's [[WP:SHIPNAME|ship name]] policy specifies that [[hull number|hull]] and [[pennant number|pennant]] numbers (e.g. USS ''Carl Vinson'' (CVN-70)) be used to disambiguate ships when appropriate. This is a change from an the older policy, which used them wherever possible, but there is at least a significant minority that still favors the approach.

:Why should a general reader with no knowledge about warships know that they would need to type in something like [[USS Carl Vinson (CVN-70)|(CVN-70)]]? At best, this is useless [[WP:JARGON|jargon]] for non-specialists. Worse, an argument for consistency falls flat when only a minority of countries use them; we only have these numbers for American and British/some Commonwealth ships. Now:
:*With American [[hull classification symbol]]s, it's a lot of unneeded fluff in the title, and [[WP:PRECISE]] should force us to drop it (unless another ship shared the same name, obviously). These numbers have been changed in a non-trivial number of cases, like the {{sclass-|Knox|frigate|1}}.
:*With British [[pennant number]]s, they're reused. If you can honestly tell me what ship {{HMS|Ark Royal|91}} is without looking or guessing, I'll give you a cookie. Not a single person can argue that pennant numbers are helpful to a general reader when they type a ship name in the search bar. As my colleague {{u|Parsecboy}} said, "Which is more helpful to non-experts trying to find the WWII Ark Royal in the auto-fill drop down - a list of articles with (91), (R07), and (R09) as dabs, or a list of articles with (1937), (1950), and (1981) as dabs?"

So given that it's pretty apparent that we've been perpetuating a system that is completely useless to helping our readers, '''I'm proposing that [[WP:SHIPNAME]] be changed to mandate the use of launch dates rather than hull numbers when disambiguation is necessary.''' [[Wikipedia:Naming_conventions_(ships)#Disambiguating_ships_with_the_same_name|We already do this]] for ships that predate hull numbers, and such a system would be ''far'' easier to navigate for our readers, who (a) are why we are here and (b) again, typically have little to no specialist knowledge about ships. [[User:The ed17|Ed]]&nbsp;<sup>[[User talk:The ed17|[talk]]]&nbsp;[[WP:OMT|[majestic titan]]]</sup> 16:58, 26 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of most widely spoken languages (by number of countries)#rfc_4C7A482|Talk:List of most widely spoken languages (by number of countries)]] expired 2015-05-26 17:00 ===
* Id: 4C7A482
* User: Archon 2488
* Date: 2015-04-26 16:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|659334075|LANG 659334075}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|664143994|LANG 664143994}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I've looked over this article and tried to fix a few inconsistencies and other problems. I don't accept some claims above that the article is so irredeemable that it should be deleted; it just needs to be made more consistent. But a couple of serious questions need to be answered before it can be improved, and these are my suggested answers:

1) What kinds of political entity count? 
* Sovereign states: obviously. 
* Overseas territories (including anomalies like China's SARs and the UK's Crown Dependencies): maybe, but needs to be done consistently. List all or none.
* Disputed (partially recognised) states like Transnistria: serious [[WP:OR]] and [[WP:NPOV]] dangers here. If these entities are to be listed at all, their anomalous constitutional status must be emphasised. Implying (even by omission) that they are equivalent to undisputed sovereign states is an egregious NPOV violation. Moreover, facts about such small and obscure territories (beyond "the somewhat dubious constitution scribbled down in the middle of a civil war says that the official language is X") can be hard to verify independently.
* Sub-national entities (e.g. South Tyrol, states and provinces of federal countries): probably not. To apply this fairly, if you want to say that Quebec speaks French and South Tyrol speaks German you'd need to list every single Russian federal subject and say they all speak Russian, every US and Australian state and Canadian province except Quebec and say they speak English, etc.
* Micronations (e.g. Sealand): No. NPOV, OR and all the rest of it.

2) What exactly is the criterion for "being spoken" in a country?
* Official/national language of the country: yes, this doesn't seem to be in dispute.
* Clear majority language even if not official (e.g. for countries like the USA, UK and Australia which do not have ''de jure'' official languages): yes, ''de facto'' much the same as above.
* Minority languages: No; serious potential problems with [[WP:OR]] and [[WP:NPOV]] here. I removed an assertion that Russian is a language of Israel; even if there is a large minority of Russian speakers due to immigration from the USSR, the language is not officially recognised and I see no evidence that it is the majority language of Israel.
* Languages with official recognition as "regional languages" or similar: No, generally not notable enough (same argument as above relating to languages spoken in individual states and provinces of countries, regardless of whether there is official recognition of the language).
* Historical association with a country or territory: No; I removed Goa from the list of Portuguese-speaking countries and territories. Even aside from the fact that Goa isn't a country and we don't list the official languages of each Indian state separately (my point above), I see no evidence that Portuguese continues to be widely used in Goa. Even the [[Goa|article on Goa]] flatly contradicts this and says that Portuguese use is mostly associated with the older generations and is decreasing.

[[User:Archon 2488|Archon 2488]] ([[User talk:Archon 2488|talk]]) 16:14, 26 April 2015 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a debate on the neutrality of the following sentence:
<blockquote>A devout believer in Nichiren Buddhism in the latter half of his life, he joined the Kokuchūkai, a Nichiren Buddhist organization with nationalistic leanings, though it is unclear for how long, and what influence (if any) this had on his life and work.</blockquote>

'''[[User:Sturmgewehr88|<span style="background:black"><span style="color:red">ミーラー強斗武</span>]]</span>''' ([[User_talk:Sturmgewehr88|StG88ぬ会話]]) 19:54, 26 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Free will#rfc_8F664DA|Talk:Free will]] expired 2015-05-27 01:00 ===
* Id: 8F664DA
* User: Brews ohare
* Date: 2015-04-27 00:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|659383909|RELI 659383909}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|664201291|RELI 664201291}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Comments are invited upon changing the third paragraph in [[Free will#In Western philosophy]] to more correctly separate the different roles played by the metaphysical doctrines of [[nomological determinism]] and [[physical determinism]]. Most importantly, the paragraph is expanded to incorporate [https://books.google.com/books?id=RNOxMSiUmUkC&pg=PA16&dq=%22physical+events+and+entities+are+all+that+there+are+in+this+world,+or+that+physical+causation+is+all+the+causation+that+there+is%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h4w_VcDaK4OSyQTrnoHICg&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22physical%20events%20and%20entities%20are%20all%20that%20there%20are%20in%20this%20world%2C%20or%20that%20physical%20causation%20is%20all%20the%20causation%20that%20there%20is%22&f=false Kim's view]: "It is plain that physical casual closure...does not say that physical events and entities are all that there are in this world, or that physical causation is all the causation that there is." A possible replacement is proposed for comment. [[User:Brews ohare|Brews ohare]] ([[User talk:Brews ohare|talk]]) 00:58, 27 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Classical music#rfc_BEA9B88|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Classical music]] expired 2015-05-27 02:00 ===
* Id: BEA9B88
* User: Stfg
* Date: 2015-05-08 19:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|661460804|MEDIA 661460804}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|661460810|SOC 661460810}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|664207916|MEDIA 664207916}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|664207923|SOC 664207923}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When article titles about works by the composer [[John Ireland (composer)|John Ireland]] are disambiguated using the composer's name, should that name take the form ''John Ireland'' in all cases, or should it normally take the form ''Ireland'' and only use the form ''John Ireland'' when ''Ireland'' alone would be ambiguous or misleading?

Notes:
#This RFC is not asking whether the composer's name should be used as disambiguator, but only what form it should take when the name is chosen as a disambiguator.
#The question applies whether the name is the sole disambiguator in a given title or whether other information (e.g. a date) in used as well.
--[[User:Stfg|Stfg]] ([[User talk:Stfg|talk]]) 19:14, 8 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Scott Walker (politician)#rfc_3E194B8|Talk:Scott Walker (politician)]] expired 2015-05-27 07:00 ===
* Id: 3E194B8
* User: PrairieKid
* Date: 2015-04-27 06:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|659424193|BIO 659424193}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|659424203|POL 659424203}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|664235312|BIO 664235312}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|664235321|POL 664235321}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
Hello. There has been a bit of dispute regarding some edits I made today to this article. This is the [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Walker_(politician)&oldid=659318546 article just before I started editing it.] Basically, I created a new page, [[Political positions of Scott Walker]] and moved some of the Gubernatorial stuff over there. After reaching consensus that that article was more about his time as Governor than his political positions, I created the [[Governorship of Scott Walker]] article. I have moved quite a bit of content from the main SW article to those two and have added quite a bit of new content to those articles as well. I left summaries behind at the main article and am trying to keep everything straight. (I've done a lot of going back and forth between pages.) Most of the political articles I've worked on have gone through this process (Everything from Rand Paul to Jeb Bush to Hillary Clinton) and I think it's better. Another editor was concerned with the massive change.  '''Basically, is 3 articles better than 1?''' Should we return everything back to the main page (keeping some of the c/e I did) or keep it at three separate pages. <small>(I apologize for the length of the explanation... It's been a long day of editing!)</small> [[User:PrairieKid|PrairieKid]] ([[User talk:PrairieKid|talk]]) 06:05, 27 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Taj Mahal#rfc_30E553F|Talk:Taj Mahal]] expired 2015-05-27 11:00 ===
* Id: 30E553F
* User: The Herald
* Date: 2015-04-27 10:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|659462236|HIST 659462236}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|664256484|HIST 664256484}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been a good amount of discussion on the issue that which architectural style is used in the building. I am searching for a better answer so as to include it in the lead section and go with it to make the article more stable.

The current head says:''The Taj Mahal combines elements from [[Indian architecture|Indian]], [[Islamic architecture|Islamic]], [[Persian architecture|Persian]], [[Ottoman architecture|Turkish]] architectural styles.''

I would prefer to go with the current one as I could deduce evidently that it actually is a blend of Indian and Islamic with a slight touch of Persian and Turkish..-[[User:The Herald|The Herald]] [[User talk:The Herald|<sup style="margin-left:0.5px">''the joy of the LORD''</sup>]][[Special:Contributions/The Herald|<sub style="margin-left:-47.5px">''my strength''</sub>]] 10:11, 27 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Cite isbn#rfc_3FF6C4B|Template talk:Cite isbn]] expired 2015-05-28 00:00 ===
* Id: 3FF6C4B
* User: Curly Turkey
* Date: 2015-04-27 23:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|659583525|POLICY 659583525}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|659583530|TECH 659583530}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|664344488|POLICY 664344488}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|664344500|TECH 664344500}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
An editor has [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_isbn/doc&diff=628306262&oldid=618965438 added a template] informing users that the {{tld|cite isbn}} template has been deprecated, linking to [[Template_talk:Cite_doi/Archive_1#RfC:_Should_Template:cite_doi_cease_creating_a_separate_subpage_for_each_DOI.3F|a discussion]] at {{tl|cite doi}}, where {{tld|cite isbn}} is not discussed and the closer explicitly states ''"there is not clear numerical majority consensus"''; further, many of the arguments there don't apply to {{tld|cite isbn}}.

Now there are editors subst-ing out {{tld|cite isbn}}s (about a thousand).  It doesn't appear to me that there is anything like a consensus in support of such a move. [[User:Curly Turkey|Curly&nbsp;Turkey]]&nbsp;[[User talk:Curly Turkey|''¡gobble!'']] 23:13, 27 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Help talk:CS1 errors#rfc_6A44D1A|Help talk:CS1 errors]] expired 2015-05-28 22:00 ===
* Id: 6A44D1A
* User: Floydian
* Date: 2015-04-28 21:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|659758197|POLICY 659758197}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|664478923|POLICY 664478923}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm getting sick of this. <s>Hundreds</s>'''Thousands''' ({{cl|CS1_errors:_chapter_ignored}}) of articles are affected and now display errors where they once worked fine because of the recent conversion. There was no discussion, no attempt to implement this in a thoughtful way. Chapter, section, etc, are perfectly reasonable parameters to expect in newspapers, periodicals, websites, books, and many other form of citations. The workarounds are simply not reasonable: title? No, not part of the title. departments? No, that sticks it in-front of the title, not correct in any citation style. at? wtf is that?

Please fix this by making the previously usable parameters work. I'm tired of having to update dozens to hundreds of articles, many of which are good or featured, to remedy an undiscussed fuck-up. If someone "needs" this to be in RfC question format: Should these errors be fixed in the citation template or the numerous affected articles where it previously worked. - '''[[User:Floydian|<font color="#5A5AC5">Floydian</font>]]'''&nbsp;<sup>[[User_talk:Floydian|<font color="#3AAA3A">τ</font>]]</sup> <sub>[[Special:Contributions/Floydian|<font color="#3AAA3A">¢</font>]]</sub> 21:05, 28 April 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Identification friend or foe#rfc_05688FA|Talk:Identification friend or foe]] expired 2015-06-02 09:00 ===
* Id: 05688FA
* User: 67.165.69.4
* Date: 2015-05-31 18:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|664900099|SCI 664900099}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|665147118|SCI 665147118}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I really think the page should be moved to [[Identification Friend or Foe]] as this is the proper capitalization for an acronym. [[WP:ACRO]] is mute on the subject. It is capitalized in other, generally reliable sources, such as [http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/281888/Identification-Friend-or-Foe The title of the Encyclopædia Britannica] entry, and is capitalized as the working entry for [http://www.nrl.navy.mil/accomplishments/systems/friend-or-foe/ US Military articles] as well. Is there anyone that disagrees with this? I had attempted to [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Identification_Friend_or_Foe&type=revision&diff=664831033&oldid=175111540 speedy] the capitalization but the admin that got to it - [[User:RHaworth]] - [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Identification_Friend_or_Foe&diff=next&oldid=664831033 disagreed] with the speedy tag. As such, to determine a proper consensus, I'm adding an RFC here on the issue. [[Special:Contributions/67.165.69.4|67.165.69.4]] ([[User talk:67.165.69.4|talk]]) 18:10, 31 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Steve Jobs#rfc_38282B9|Talk:Steve Jobs]] expired 2015-06-03 01:00 ===
* Id: 38282B9
* User: Classicfilms
* Date: 2015-05-28 17:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|664447522|BIO 664447522}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|665257954|BIO 665257954}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
''(Note: Please also see the "Trivia and OR tags" thread above this post).'' I am trying to improve this article for a future GAN . I originally placed a tag on the section "Innovations and designs," but have removed it until this content dispute can be resolved. I am not disputing that discussion of each of these innovations belongs in the article. However, I feel that we need to reorganize how the information is presented. I currently read the section as a long list that is written in such a way that it is distant from the overall intent of a biography. User:Dream Focus disagrees and believes the section should stay as it is. In the thread above, I suggested that we either rewrite the section in a manner similar to the FA article [[James Joyce]], or move it to a separate article like [[Science and inventions of Leonardo da Vinci]] (calling it: "Innovations and designs of Steve Jobs"). Either way, discussion of all of the innovations needs to be expanded throughout the article, in a manner similar to the GA article [[Leonardo da Vinci]] so I am not suggesting the removing of overall content. The point is that the article needs to sound more like a cohesive biography with an explicit structure. -[[User:Classicfilms|Classicfilms]] ([[User talk:Classicfilms|talk]]) 17:51, 28 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_C6B6A3A|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2015-06-03 04:00 ===
* Id: C6B6A3A
* User: 85.211.109.208
* Date: 2015-05-07 03:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|664119500|UNSORTED 664119500}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|665275049|UNSORTED 665275049}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== A way to prevent revertwars from erupting '''

I propose a way to eliminate the current separation between the discussion and revision history pages, as it is a major cause of edit wars. For example, if one's contribution is undone (itself a much-abused tool), what is often the first instinct? To revert it! And leave a message in edit summary explaining why the undoer is wrong. They will in turn likely do the same... leaving an edit summary message saying why ''you'' are wrong. This only leads to reversion wars, because the only way to reply, to leave a message on that page, is to make an edit...
The talk page? Indeed, leave the edit conflict, go there and navigate the wall of text, ''edit'' the page (which is more cumbersome than a message box system), then try to attract the other's attention... and ''who'' is going to start the discussion? The one whose version is current doesn't care anymore, the other one only cares about making ''their'' version current!
If only messages could be posted inline on the revision history page, the whole process would become so much less reversome and smoother. The messages would be posted through a message box, and be posted on the page as expandible stubs, shown in chronological order between the revision versions. There would be clickable tags inside the messages that would scroll to the message being replied to, and tags to scroll to any replies.
If there are more than eg five or ten messages between two revisions, the list could be collapsed.
Messages posted privately from one of the users to another would show up as stubs that are only expandible by the sender and receiver. And a captcha in the messagebox would prevent spam and overuse.

The current system makes it pathologically ready to invalidate another user's contribution by deleting it entirely (which is distinctly inflammatory), and far too cumbersome to discuss changes instead. And this creates disproportionate damage when the edit in question is large, as it's more likely to be reverted. So even though most edits aren't reverted, reversion is a big problem.

Regarding undo: 'undo' is far too often a way of saying 'I sort of disagree, and can't be bothered to show subtlety'. Instead of 'undo', the button should be 'see changes' (with an edit box below a comparison of this version and the one preceeding it, and the ability to select and copy text from the two sides separately). This would encourage people to treat others' contributions with greater respect. <small class="autosigned">—&nbsp;Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/85.211.109.208|85.211.109.208]] ([[User talk:85.211.109.208|talk]]) 03:55, 7 May 2015 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_A24A149|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2015-06-03 04:00 ===
* Id: A24A149
* User: Msmarmalade
* Date: 2015-05-06 07:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|664119500|UNSORTED 664119500}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|665275049|UNSORTED 665275049}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
===Background (Persondata)'''

From [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]: {{tq|"Persondata is a special set of metadata that can and should be added to biographical articles only. It consists of standardized data fields with basic information about the person (name, short description, birth and death days, and places of birth and death) that, unlike conventional Wikipedia content, can be extracted automatically and processed by cataloging tools and then used for a variety of purposes, such as providing advanced search capabilities, statistical analysis, automated categorization, and birthday lists."}}

The question of whether to delete {{tl|Persondata}} has been visited in the past, the motivation being that [[Wikidata]] (and infoboxes) now provides better functionality, making Persondata obsolete. The main concern from [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)/Archive 113#RfC: Should Persondata template be removed from articles?|the last RfC]] was that it was too soon, and that the info from Persondata should be copied to Wikidata before any deleting should be considered. Since then, a [[Wikipedia:Templates for discussion/Log/2014 October 17#Template:Persondata|TfD ruled the template deprecated]], but as there were only 4 users participating (compared with the ~50 users in the RfC) no action was put in motion to stop adding new templates.

In the meantime, [[wikidata:User:PLbot|PLbot]] has now copied all of {{para|SHORT DESCRIPTION}} to Wikidata ([[wikidata:User talk:Pasleim#Import SHORT DESCRIPTION from Persondata|link]]). In various conversations, all other fields of Persondata have been argued to be too unreliable for any meaningful use. The bot request for copying the data to Wikidata is closed ([[wikidata:Wikidata:Bot_requests/Archive/2014/10#Final_conclusion|archived]]), and Wikidata isn't interested in the remaining Persondata fields.

;Faults of Persondata:
*Problems with name sorting, formatting guidelines not always followed, and there are also names like "Otto von Bismarck" or "Martin Luther King Jr" which are often mislabeled. ([[wikidata:Wikidata:Property proposal/Generic#Sort key|link]], [[wikidata:Wikidata:Bot_requests/Archive/2014/10#Import_Persondata_from_English_Wikipedia|link]])
*Problems with date formatting, also dates before a certain time are unreliable as Gregorian and Julian formats are indistinguishable ([[wikidata:Wikidata:Bot_requests/Archive/2014/10#Import_Persondata_from_English_Wikipedia|link]]). Also, dates rarely have references ([[Wikipedia talk:Persondata#Birth and death dates references.|link]])
*Problems with location disambiguation; formatting and when there is no link markup, or too much link markup ([[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Persondata/Archive 2#Place of birth through the ages|link]], [[wikidata:Wikidata:Bot_requests/Archive/2014/10#Import_Persondata_from_English_Wikipedia|link]], [[Wikipedia talk:Persondata/Archive 7#Overlinking in Persondata|link]]) 
*It is not used by anyone that I know of (Periglio is now using Wikidata)
*[[User:Periglio/Wikidata]]: Analysis of accuracy of Persondata vs Wikidata. 
*[[User:Pigsonthewing/Persondata]]: explains some additional problems with persondata

;Reasons to keep Persondata:
* If anyone is currently using it.
* If the parameters other than short description can be shown to be useful and worth keeping.
* If any future use cannot be replaced by Wikidata.

;Rough plan
I have compiled a rough plan of how Persondata will be migrated to Wikidata and eventually deleted (A more detailed version can be found [[User:Msmarmalade/Persondata#Rough Plan|here]]). This is my own plan, and doesn't necessarily have to be the way we do it. I am only mentioning it here so I don't give the impression that this RfC is to delete Persondata immediately. Please discuss below if you have any suggestions.

# Transfer {{para|SHORT DESCRIPTION}} across to Wikidata. {{Done}}
# Stop bots from automatically creating new Persondata templates.
# Notify users in relevant projects of deprecation.
# Transfer any new data to Wikidata, then remove methodically.
# Close the template and relevant pages when ready.

'''Questions:'''
#Is anyone still using Persondata?
#*Are any Wikidata bots still extracting Persondata for new/revised articles?
#Can Persondata be considered deprecated and no longer added to articles?
#Is short description the only useful parameter?
#'''Main Question:''' Should the {{Tl|Persondata}} template be methodically removed from articles and no longer be used?

Proposed by [[User:Msmarmalade|Msmarmalade]] ([[User talk:Msmarmalade|talk]]) 07:23, 6 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:No original research#rfc_D3FE7B7|Wikipedia talk:No original research]] expired 2015-06-03 08:00 ===
* Id: D3FE7B7
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2015-06-03 01:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|665263845|POLICY 665263845}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|669719308|POLICY 669719308}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per the above discussion, clarify and normalize the following:
* "Unless restricted by another policy, primary sources that have been reliably published may be used in Wikipedia"
to read:
* "Unless restricted by another policy, primary sources from reputable publishers may be used in Wikipedia"
so that the wording agrees with [[WP:Reliable sources]].

Reputability of a publisher (how well-regarded it is) is directly addressed at [[WP:Reliable sources]], but the terms "reliable"/"reliability" are never used there to refer to a publisher, and as detailed above, cannot logically apply. In short form: Sources may be ''reliable'' (a determination Wikipedia makes internally, with a whole guideline full of criteria); a publisher may be ''reputable'', a quality that WP:RS indicates we observe about the off-WP world's regard for the publisher. <span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'"> — [[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''' ☺]] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|☏]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¢]] ≽<sup>ʌ</sup>ⱷ҅<sub>ᴥ</sub>ⱷ<sup>ʌ</sup>≼ </span> 01:57, 3 June 2015 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{U|Scottperry}} has suggested reverting the article [[Psychiatry]] to a [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Psychiatry&oldid=499825194#Transinstitutionalization_and_the_aftermath revision of 28 June 2012]. The editor argues that this is necessary to address issues of [[WP:UNDUE]] in the [[Psychiatry#Controversy|controversy]] section of the current version of the article. They also argue that the article has experienced a general degradation of wording and phrasing compared to the 28 June 2012 revision. Regardless of whether the proposed reversion is justified, in the interests of article stability, it might be worthwhile to solicit a wider spectrum of opinion before applying such wide-ranging changes. A more detailed presentation of the arguments for this change can be found in the section above or in the following diffs [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3APsychiatry&type=revision&diff=664893515&oldid=637720395] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3APsychiatry&type=revision&diff=665194179&oldid=664924323] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3APsychiatry&type=revision&diff=665214321&oldid=665202625]. === [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Japan-related articles#rfc_F3A783E|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Japan-related articles]] expired 2015-06-05 06:00 ===
* Id: F3A783E
* User: Fernando Danger
* Date: 2015-05-28 02:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|664356796|STYLE 664356796}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|668852637|STYLE 668852637}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
According to [[WP:JTITLE]], Japanese born prior to 1868 should be given family name first while those born later should be given family name last. In general, academic usage is to put family name first, while journalists tend to put family name last. As near as I can tell, the idea of using a specific year as a cutoff is unique to Wikipedia. I have created the following options to allow editors to express preference. For example, "BACD" indicates that "B" is the editor's first preference, "A" second, and so forth. [[User:Fernando Danger|Fernando Danger]] ([[User talk:Fernando Danger|talk]]) 02:50, 28 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing#rfc_F45E3AF|Talk:Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing]] expired 2015-06-05 07:00 ===
* Id: F45E3AF
* User: 73.223.96.73
* Date: 2015-05-06 06:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|661064662|SCI 661064662}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|665584714|SCI 665584714}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been some discussion over how to describe the current status of EMDR in the lead paragraph.  Currently, the lead contains a paragraph describing endorsements by several organizations, and then mentioning that the issue has been controversial in the past.  This paragraph misrepresents the situation by (a) presenting an appearance of overwhelming support and endorsement for the therapy, when in fact the support is more measured and moderate, and (b) minimizing the past controversy over the treatment's efficacy and the ongoing debate over its mechanisms.  This RfC is for the purpose of crafting a more accurate paragraph, free from advocacy and bias. [[Special:Contributions/73.223.96.73|73.223.96.73]] ([[User talk:73.223.96.73|talk]]) 06:54, 6 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Central Intelligence Agency#rfc_041A8D0|Talk:Central Intelligence Agency]] expired 2015-06-06 15:00 ===
* Id: 041A8D0
* User: Northamerica1000
* Date: 2015-05-07 14:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|661261690|POL 661261690}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|665765589|POL 665765589}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
To reduce page length, a [[WP:SPINOUT]] was created that moved content from [[Central Intelligence Agency]] to [[History of the Central Intelligence Agency]]. This has now been reverted twice by one user. Per the editing guideline [[WP:SIZERULE]], articles over 100 kilobytes should "almost certainly should be divided". The article is presently at <s>172</s> 97 kilobytes readable prose size. Users in threads above on the talk page have suggested that this split of the History section would serve to functionally reduce the page's size and better-organize it, while others have opposed this. Some have also suggested additional various means to reduce the page's length. <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">[[User:Northamerica1000|North America]]<sup>[[User talk:Northamerica1000|<font size="-2">1000</font>]]</sup></span> 14:25, 7 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Musicians#rfc_AF51E37|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Musicians]] expired 2015-06-06 16:00 ===
* Id: AF51E37
* User: Vortiene
* Date: 2015-05-07 15:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|661268877|TECH 661268877}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|665772275|TECH 665772275}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It seems the most commonly utilized timeline templates within band articles require a specific end date set for the timeline. This is perfect for bands that have completed their career, say the band split up in 2002. However, for active bands, this needs to be updated on various occasions to maintain the appearance of the timeline. 

What I'm proposing here is that instead of inserting a random future date into the timeline, we utilize wikipedia functionality to place the current date for active bands. I'd like to have a consensus of whether we should have a rolling end date for active artists/band timeline templates, or keep the current method of iteratively extending timelines for active bands by setting the end date to a date in the future not too far off. Instead of putting future dates, we can put the current date, since technically, the band is active until the current date, (we don't know if they will be active in the future for sure). 

'''Discussion'''

How is this done? We can utilize the following code to place a rolling-end date in timelines, as such:

{{code|<nowiki>{{#time: d/m/Y }}</nowiki>}}

which results in

{{code|{{#time: d/m/Y }}}}

alternatively, the following

{{code|<nowiki>{{#time: m/d/Y }}</nowiki>}}

can be used as well depending on the date format in the timeline.

In the case of a timeline, for example, the timeline of the band [[Lost Horizon (band)|Lost Horizon]] we have:

{{markup|<nowiki>
{{#tag:timeline|
ImageSize = width:700 height:auto barincrement:20
PlotArea = left:90 bottom:60 top:0 right:15
Alignbars = justify
DateFormat = mm/dd/yyyy
Period = from:12/25/1990 till:{{#time: m/d/Y }}
TimeAxis = orientation:horizontal format:yyyy
Legend = orientation:horizontal position:bottom
ScaleMajor = increment:2 start:1991
ScaleMinor = increment:2 start:1992

Colors =
 id:Vocals    value:red    legend:Vocals
 id:Guitars   value:green  legend:Guitars
 id:Bass      value:blue   legend:Bass
 id:Keys      value:purple legend:Synthesisers
 id:Drums     value:orange legend:Drums
 id:Lines1    value:black  legend:Studio_Releases

LineData =
 at:05/08/2001 color:Lines1 layer:back
 at:06/24/2003 color:Lines1 layer:back

BarData =
 bar:Cans text:"Joacim Cans"
 bar:Heiman text:"Daniel Heiman"

 bar:Lisicki text:"Wojtek Lisicki"
 bar:Olsson  text:"Fredrik Olsson"

 bar:Furangen text:"Martin Furängen"

 bar:Publik text:"Attila Publik"

 bar:Nyquist text:"Christian Nyquist"

PlotData=
 width:10 textcolor:black align:left anchor:from shift:(10,-4)
 bar:Cans from:12/25/1990 till:10/13/1999 color:Vocals
 bar:Heiman from:10/14/1999 till:05/14/2005 color:Vocals

 bar:Lisicki from:12/25/1990 till:09/25/2003 color:Guitars
 bar:Olsson from:07/02/2002 till:05/14/2005 color:Guitars
 bar:Lisicki from:07/25/2004 till:end color:Guitars

 bar:Furangen from:12/25/1990 till:end color:Bass

 bar:Publik from:07/02/2002 till:end color:Keys

 bar:Nyquist from:12/25/1990 till:end color:Drums

}}</nowiki>
|{{#tag:timeline|
ImageSize = width:700 height:auto barincrement:20
PlotArea = left:90 bottom:60 top:0 right:15
Alignbars = justify
DateFormat = mm/dd/yyyy
Period = from:12/25/1990 till:{{#time: m/d/Y }}
TimeAxis = orientation:horizontal format:yyyy
Legend = orientation:horizontal position:bottom
ScaleMajor = increment:2 start:1991
ScaleMinor = increment:2 start:1992

Colors =
 id:Vocals    value:red    legend:Vocals
 id:Guitars   value:green  legend:Guitars
 id:Bass      value:blue   legend:Bass
 id:Keys      value:purple legend:Synthesisers
 id:Drums     value:orange legend:Drums
 id:Lines1    value:black  legend:Studio_Releases

LineData =
 at:05/08/2001 color:Lines1 layer:back
 at:06/24/2003 color:Lines1 layer:back

BarData =
 bar:Cans text:"Joacim Cans"
 bar:Heiman text:"Daniel Heiman"

 bar:Lisicki text:"Wojtek Lisicki"
 bar:Olsson  text:"Fredrik Olsson"

 bar:Furangen text:"Martin Furängen"

 bar:Publik text:"Attila Publik"

 bar:Nyquist text:"Christian Nyquist"

PlotData=
 width:10 textcolor:black align:left anchor:from shift:(10,-4)
 bar:Cans from:12/25/1990 till:10/13/1999 color:Vocals
 bar:Heiman from:10/14/1999 till:05/14/2005 color:Vocals

 bar:Lisicki from:12/25/1990 till:09/25/2003 color:Guitars
 bar:Olsson from:07/02/2002 till:05/14/2005 color:Guitars
 bar:Lisicki from:07/25/2004 till:end color:Guitars

 bar:Furangen from:12/25/1990 till:end color:Bass

 bar:Publik from:07/02/2002 till:end color:Keys

 bar:Nyquist from:12/25/1990 till:end color:Drums

}}}}


as you can see the current date is the end date of the timeline. Notice however that {{code|<nowiki>{{#tag:timeline|Insert timeline body here}}</nowiki>}} rather than {{code|<nowiki><timeline>Insert timeline body here</timeline></nowiki>}} must be used to declare the timeline, however, for this to work properly. 

This is a minor modification, however it removes a consistent maintenance step for articles that isn't really needed, and isn't necessarily simple to rectify through the template itself without making a template specifically for active bands. (It is a timeline template after all, not a band timeline template.) I think it should be employed on articles with active bands. However, I'd like to hear what people think about it. One qualm I have is that people may not like the idea that a future release cannot be marked on the timeline beforehand. I think this isn't too much of an issue, since the timeline shouldn't necessarily run into the future, and the article itself can cover information on a future release. 

I'm not proposing we have a huge task force go through every article, this is rather an approach to having a reason to prevent people from changing timelines not to have a rolling end date if we decide this is something that should happen on active band/artist articles. Rolling end dates can be added gradually, and there wouldn't be a particularly good reason for removing these end dates as it would add extra article maintenance.

[[User:Vortiene|Vortiene]] ([[User talk:Vortiene|talk]]) 15:49, 7 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Dennis Hastert#rfc_FE00580|Talk:Dennis Hastert]] expired 2015-06-07 23:00 ===
* Id: FE00580
* Date: 2015-06-03 09:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|665302911|BIO 665302911}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|665302914|POL 665302914}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|665955501|BIO 665955501}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|665955506|POL 665955506}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a dispute as to coverage of the recent indictment in the lede. There is no obvious dispute as to the factual accuracy of the material, or its inclusion within the article as a whole. An indictment is not a conviction. Hastert's role in the Clinton indictment evokes schadenfreude, against which we must of course guard. 

The text at time of posting this RfC is:

:In May 2015, Hastert was indicted for allegedly [[structuring]] bank withdrawals to evade bank reporting requirements and then [[making false statements]] to federal investigators.<ref name="Indictment">{{cite |author=United States District Court, Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, Federal Grand Jury Indictment |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.documentcloud.org/documents/2089608/indictment-of-former-house-speaker-dennis-hastert.pdf |date=February 2014 |title=Federal Grand Jury Indictment}}</ref><ref name="Yahoo"/> Prosecutors said that the money was to compensate for and conceal misconduct by Hastert against an individual more than three decades earlier.<ref>{{cite news |author= |title=Hastert charged with lying to FBI |url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20150528/news/150528710/ |newspaper=[[Chicago Daily Herald]] |location=Chicago |date=May 28, 2015 |access-date=2015-06-02}}</ref>

{{reflist-talk}}

The possibilities appear to be:

# Omit any mention in the lede.
# Mention with a short sentence, shorter than the present text.
# Use the present text.
# Use the present text but append Hastert's response.
# Use something longer than the present text.

Please indicate which of the options, if any, you support. <b>[[User Talk:JzG|Guy]]</b> <small>([[User:JzG/help|Help!]])</small> 09:25, 3 June 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Paranormal activity#rfc_1E5126E|Talk:Paranormal activity]] expired 2015-06-07 23:00 ===
* Id: 1E5126E
* User: Krychek
* Date: 2015-05-08 18:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|661452764|MEDIA 661452764}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|661452779|SOC 661452779}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|665955505|MEDIA 665955505}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|665955512|SOC 665955512}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
At the moment, this page redirects to [[Paranormal]], a general article about paranormal phenomena. There have been numerous attempts to redirect the search "Paranormal activity" to [[Paranormal Activity]], an article about the 2007 film. These attempts are invariably reverted, most recently with the comment that the change was done without consensus. Yet no attempt has ever been made to determine actual consensus. So I ask: Should "Paranormal activity" redirect to "Paranormal Activity" as a simple capitalization shift? Note that each of the articles in question already contains a hatnote referring to the other. [[User:Krychek|Krychek]] ([[User talk:Krychek|talk]]) 18:45, 8 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2015 Kumanovo shootings#rfc_E3A6381|Talk:2015 Kumanovo shootings]] expired 2015-06-09 00:01 ===
* Id: E3A6381
* User: AnulBanul
* Date: 2015-05-09 23:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|661626139|HIST 661626139}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|661626146|POL 661626146}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|666113380|HIST 666113380}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|666113381|POL 666113381}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the the title of this article be [[Battle of Kumanovo (2015)]], [[2015 Kumanovo shootings]], or [[2015 Kumanovo clashes]]?

* '''Comment:''' I support the original title, the one I have made - 2015 Kumanovo clashes. The reason is simple. Kumanovo shooting would mean there was a minor incident, where a lone wolf got into some building and started shooting, for example like in the [[2015 Zvornik police station shooting]]. Therefore, the name would be misleading. The second name, Battle of Kumanovo, is also misleading, but in an opposite direction. It would mean there was a major confrontation, which it wasn't. There were clashes, and only this term is appropriate for this event. --[[User:AnulBanul|AnulBanul]] ([[User talk:AnulBanul|talk]]) 23:40, 9 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2012 Delhi gang rape#rfc_8CF20AF|Talk:2012 Delhi gang rape]] expired 2015-06-09 12:00 ===
* Id: 8CF20AF
* User: Kenfyre
* Date: 2015-05-10 11:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|661686957|HIST 661686957}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|666174938|HIST 666174938}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The article makes the following claim:
''In the 33-page charge sheet, the Delhi Police described the juvenile as the most brutal of the six accused.'' 
The following articles are used as citation: 
* [http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/01/04/juvenile-suspect-in-india-gang-rape-reportedly-ripped-her-intestines-out-in/, 4 January 2013, Fox News]: "The paper reported that a charge sheet on the case suggests the juvenile suspect assaulted the female student twice and pulled out her intestines with his bare hands. The juvenile—who Delhi police have not identified ''while they determine his exact age''—also wanted to strip the victim naked and throw her off the moving bus."
* [http://www.hindustantimes.com/chunk-ht-ui-indiasectionpage-delhigangrape/most-brutal-of-delhi-rape-accused-waits-to-know-his-fate/article1-984606.aspx, 4 January 2013, Hindustan Times]: "Two days after he was nabbed on December 28, the police had applied to the Juvenile Justice Board (JJB) for a ''bone ossification test'' of the juvenile -- who, according to police, had subjected the victim to the most inhuman physical and sexual torture. The Delhi Police, at the moment, is ''treating him as a juvenile purely on the basis of a school leaving certificate'' obtained from a school in Badaun, UP." 
* [http://www.hindustantimes.com/newdelhi/delhi-gangrape-sixth-accused-sent-to-police-custody-for-a-day/article1-981568.aspx 27 December 2012, Hindustan Times]: This article makes no mention of any brutality by the juvenile. 
* [http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/chargesheet-filed-in-delhi-gangrape-case/article4269315.ece 3 January 2013, The Hindu]:  This article makes no mention of any brutality by the juvenile. 

Now, I found a later article that has not been used: 
* [http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/not-juvenile-brutal-delhi-gangrape-assailant-now-faces-death-not-freedom/1062581/ 21 January 2013, The Indian Express]: "...it was revealed today that a ''bone ossification test'' of Vinay Sharma, one of the six accused, has proved that he was not a juvenile, and therefore, could be tried under the existing laws governing rape cases in the country. Law enforcement and forensic authorities said that as per the tests, Sharma is 19 and not below 18 as he had earlier claimed."

So, it seems that the accusations of brutality were directed at Vinay Sharma who was tried as an adult and not the unnamed juvenile. The incident has also been described in [http://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/rape_verdict.pdf the judgement] but the juvenile has not been accused of any extra brutality. I think the original editors have had a mistake confusing Vinay Sharma with the unnamed juvenile. I think we should remove the sentence about brutality, until we can examine the actual police chargesheet or the verdict of juvenile court, because media reports are confusing.

-[[User:Kenfyre|<font color="#666FFF ">'''Ken'''</font><font color="#FF3C00">'''fyre'''</font>]] ([[User talk:Kenfyre|talk]]) 11:45, 10 May 2015 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Edward Snowden#rfc_4A633C9|Talk:Edward Snowden]] expired 2015-06-10 01:00 ===
* Id: 4A633C9
* User: Kent Krupa
* Date: 2015-06-08 18:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|666068295|BIO 666068295}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|666068311|POL 666068311}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|666271595|BIO 666271595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|666271597|POL 666271597}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The length and content of the lead to [[Edward Snowden]] have been historically contentious. On 4 June 2015, [[User:DrFleischman|Dr. Fleischman]] inserted a Lead Too Long template, stating in his edit summary: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Edward_Snowden&type=revision&diff=665542244&oldid=665541830 "lead too long - too much detail."] That triggered a round of revisions and reversions, [[Talk:Edward_Snowden#Size_of_lead|as discussed here,]] [[Talk:Edward_Snowden#Request_for_clarification_as_to_lead_length_and_NPOV|that in turn]] forged consensus (a) that the lead ought to be shortened and (b) agreeing upon a process of submitting each proposed edit to [[Talk:Edward_Snowden#Proposed_text_to_trim_the_lead|the talk page]] for acceptance or rejection.<p>
[[User:Petrarchan47|Petrarchan47]], who has contributed more to this bio than anyone else [https://tools.wmflabs.org/usersearch/usersearch.py?name=Petrarchan47&page=Edward+Snowden&server=enwiki&max=500 (1,330 edits—17.31% of the total)] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3AEdward_Snowden&type=revision&diff=665990586&oldid=665990216 then commented:] "DrFleischman, seeing that we have agreed on a process to trim the Lede (via proposal submissions), I wonder if you would be willing to remove the tag; its purpose to alert fellow editors has been served, and Kent makes good points."<p>
My points to which she referred [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3AEdward_Snowden&type=revision&diff=665990216&oldid=665986012 include:] "…it is embarrassing. The first thing visitors see is a page-width banner proclaiming our inability to get the first four paragraphs right. What are readers to infer about the rest of the article? Edward Snowden is a mature BLP, created two years ago, that ranks [http://stats.grok.se/en/latest/Edward_Snowden within the top 600 articles] in traffic on en.wikipedia.org. It has undergone [https://tools.wmflabs.org/xtools-articleinfo/index.php?article=Edward_Snowden&lang=en&wiki=Wikipedia 7,685 revisions by a combined 1,295 editors.] … In particular, the lead has remained essentially unchanged for months. For us now to be suddenly debating its length—and its content hard won by consensus—is an admission of negligence if not incompetence. It deserves to be expeditiously addressed."<p>
However, Dr. Fleischman [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3AEdward_Snowden&type=revision&diff=665997266&oldid=665997068 responded:] "I'd actually prefer to keep the tag until the issue is resolved. If editors come along having been alerted by the tag, that would be a good thing."<p>
I respectfully invite others to weigh in on this disagreement, which is not a dispute but would benefit from input by the wider editorial community than just the handful of us involved in maintaining Snowden's BLP. [[User:Kent Krupa|Kent Krupa]] ([[User talk:Kent Krupa|talk]]) 18:07, 8 June 2015 (UTC)}}
